      <p>The enormous size of Russia and the remoteness of many areas from the sea result in the dominance of the <a href="/wiki/Humid_continental_climate" title="Humid continental climate">humid continental climate</a>, which is prevalent in all parts of the country except for the tundra and the extreme southwest. Mountains in the south obstruct the flow of warm air masses from the Indian Ocean, while the plain of the west and north makes the country open to Arctic and Atlantic influences.<sup id="cite_ref-congress_150-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-congress-150">[143]</a></sup> Most of Northern European Russia and Siberia has a <a href="/wiki/Subarctic_climate" title="Subarctic climate">subarctic climate</a>, with extremely severe winters in the inner regions of Northeast Siberia (mostly the <a href="/wiki/Sakha_Republic" class="mw-redirect" title="Sakha Republic">Sakha Republic</a>, where the Northern <a href="/wiki/Pole_of_Cold" title="Pole of Cold">Pole of Cold</a> is located with the record low temperature of â71.2&nbsp;Â°C or â96.2&nbsp;Â°F), and more moderate winters elsewhere. Both the strip of land along the shore of the Arctic Ocean and the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Arctic_islands" title="Russian Arctic islands">Russian Arctic islands</a> have a <a href="/wiki/Polar_climate" title="Polar climate">polar climate</a>. </p>
      <p>The coastal part of <a href="/wiki/Krasnodar_Krai" title="Krasnodar Krai">Krasnodar Krai</a> on the Black Sea, most notably in <a href="/wiki/Sochi" title="Sochi">Sochi</a>, possesses a <a href="/wiki/Humid_subtropical_climate" title="Humid subtropical climate">humid subtropical climate</a> with mild and wet winters. In many regions of East Siberia and the Far East, winter is dry compared to summer; other parts of the country experience more even precipitation across seasons. Winter precipitation in most parts of the country usually falls as snow. The region along the Lower Volga and Caspian Sea coast, as well as some areas of southernmost Siberia, possesses a <a href="/wiki/Semi-arid_climate" title="Semi-arid climate">semi-arid climate</a>. </p>
      <p>Throughout much of the territory there are only two distinct seasonsâwinter and summerâas spring and autumn are usually brief periods of change between extremely low and extremely high temperatures.<sup id="cite_ref-congress_150-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-congress-150">[143]</a></sup> The coldest month is January (February on the coastline); the warmest is usually July. Great ranges of temperature are typical. In winter, temperatures get colder both from south to north and from west to east. Summers can be quite hot, even in Siberia.<sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">[144]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Biodiversity">Biodiversity</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/List_of_ecoregions_in_Russia" title="List of ecoregions in Russia">List of ecoregions in Russia</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_mammals_of_Russia" title="List of mammals of Russia">List of mammals of Russia</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_birds_of_Russia" title="List of birds of Russia">List of birds of Russia</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_freshwater_fish_of_Russia" title="List of freshwater fish of Russia">List of freshwater fish of Russia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_of_Russia" title="Wildlife of Russia">Wildlife of Russia</a>
      </div> 
      <p>From north to south the <a href="/wiki/East_European_Plain" title="East European Plain">East European Plain</a>, is clad sequentially in Arctic <a href="/wiki/Tundra" title="Tundra">tundra</a>, <a href="/wiki/Taiga" title="Taiga">taiga</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mixed_and_broad-leaf_forests" class="mw-redirect" title="Mixed and broad-leaf forests">mixed and broad-leaf forests</a>, <a href="/wiki/Steppe" title="Steppe">steppe</a>, and semi-desert (fringing the Caspian Sea), as the changes in vegetation reflect the changes in climate. Siberia supports a similar sequence but is largely taiga. Russia has the world's largest <a href="/wiki/Forest_reserves" class="mw-redirect" title="Forest reserves">forest reserves</a>, known as the "Lungs of Europe";<sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152">[145]</a></sup> which is second only to the <a href="/wiki/Amazon_Rainforest" class="mw-redirect" title="Amazon Rainforest">Amazon Rainforest</a> in the amount of <a href="/wiki/Carbon_dioxide" title="Carbon dioxide">carbon dioxide</a> it absorbs. </p>
      <p>There are 266 mammal species and 780 bird species in Russia. A total of 415 animal species were included in the <a href="/wiki/Red_Data_Book_of_the_Russian_Federation" title="Red Data Book of the Russian Federation">RDBRF</a> in 1997; and are now protected.<sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153">[146]</a></sup> There are 40 <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> <a href="/wiki/Biosphere_reserve" class="mw-redirect" title="Biosphere reserve">biosphere reserves</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">[147]</a></sup> 41 <a href="/wiki/National_parks_of_Russia" title="National parks of Russia">national parks</a> and 101 <a href="/wiki/Zapovednik" title="Zapovednik">nature reserves</a>. Russia still has many ecosystems which are still untouched by manâmainly in the northern <a href="/wiki/Taiga" title="Taiga">taiga</a> areas, and in subarctic tundra of <a href="/wiki/Siberia" title="Siberia">Siberia</a>. Over time Russia has been having improvement and application of <a href="/wiki/Environmental_legislation" class="mw-redirect" title="Environmental legislation">environmental legislation</a>, development and implementation of various federal and regional strategies and programmes, and study, inventory and protection of rare and endangered plants, animals, and other organisms, and including them in the RDBRF.<sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155">[148]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Russia" title="Economy of Russia">Economy of Russia</a>
      </div>
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Economic_history_of_the_Russian_Federation" title="Economic history of the Russian Federation">Economic history of the Russian Federation</a> and <a href="/wiki/Taxation_in_Russia" title="Taxation in Russia">Taxation in Russia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Business_Centre_of_Moscow_2.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Business_Centre_of_Moscow_2.jpg/220px-Business_Centre_of_Moscow_2.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Business_Centre_of_Moscow_2.jpg/330px-Business_Centre_of_Moscow_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Business_Centre_of_Moscow_2.jpg/440px-Business_Centre_of_Moscow_2.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1500" data-file-height="1000"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Business_Centre_of_Moscow_2.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Moscow_International_Business_Center" title="Moscow International Business Center">Moscow</a> is a major <a href="/wiki/Financial_centre" title="Financial centre">financial hub</a> in Europe.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:HDP_PPP_per_capita_Russia.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/HDP_PPP_per_capita_Russia.jpg/220px-HDP_PPP_per_capita_Russia.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="143" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/HDP_PPP_per_capita_Russia.jpg/330px-HDP_PPP_per_capita_Russia.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/HDP_PPP_per_capita_Russia.jpg/440px-HDP_PPP_per_capita_Russia.jpg 2x" data-file-width="961" data-file-height="624"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:HDP_PPP_per_capita_Russia.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Russia's GDP growth by purchasing power parity (PPP) during 1991â2019 in <a href="/wiki/International_dollars" class="mw-redirect" title="International dollars">international dollars</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Russia has an upper-middle income <a href="/wiki/Mixed_economy" title="Mixed economy">mixed economy</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-https://datahelpdesk.worldbank.org_156-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-https://datahelpdesk.worldbank.org-156">[149]</a></sup> with enormous natural resources, particularly <a href="/wiki/Russian_oil_industry" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian oil industry">oil</a> and natural gas. It has the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">eleventh-largest economy</a> by nominal GDP and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP)">sixth-largest</a> by <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">PPP</a>. According to the World Bank, Russia's GDP per capita by PPP was $29,181 in 2019.<sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">[150]</a></sup> The average nominal salary in Russia was â½47,867 per month in 2019,<sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158">[151]</a></sup> and approximately 12.9% of Russians lived <a href="/wiki/Poverty_by_country" class="mw-redirect" title="Poverty by country">below the national poverty line</a> in 2018.<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">[152]</a></sup> Unemployment in Russia was 4.5% in 2019,<sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160">[153]</a></sup> and officially more than 70% of the Russian population is categorised as middle class;<sup id="cite_ref-161" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-161">[154]</a></sup> though some experts disagree with that.<sup id="cite_ref-162" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-162">[155]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163">[156]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164">[157]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165">[158]</a></sup> By the end of December 2019, Russian foreign trade turnover reached $666.6 billion. Russia's exports totalled over $422.8 billion, while its imported goods were worth over $243.8 billion.<sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">[159]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Oil, natural gas, metals, and timber account for more than 80% of Russian exports abroad.<sup id="cite_ref-cia_121-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-121">[116]</a></sup> As of 2012<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Russia&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, the oil-and-gas sector accounted for 16% of <a href="/wiki/GDP" class="mw-redirect" title="GDP">GDP</a>, 52% of federal budget revenues and over 80% of total exports.<sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167">[160]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-EIA_168-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EIA-168">[161]</a></sup> As of August&nbsp;2020<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Russia&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, foreign reserves in Russia are $438 billion.<sup id="cite_ref-169" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-169">[162]</a></sup> Russia has <a href="/wiki/Foreign_debt_by_country" class="mw-redirect" title="Foreign debt by country">one of the lowest foreign debts among major economies</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170">[163]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Russia ranks 28th of 190 countries in the 2019 <a href="/wiki/Ease_of_doing_business_index" title="Ease of doing business index">ease of doing business index</a>. It has a <a href="/wiki/Flat_tax" title="Flat tax">flat tax</a> rate of 13%; and is the country with the world's second most attractive personal tax system for single managers after the <a href="/wiki/United_Arab_Emirates" title="United Arab Emirates">United Arab Emirates</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171">[164]</a></sup> Inequality of household income and wealth has also been noted, with <a href="/wiki/Credit_Suisse" title="Credit Suisse">Credit Suisse</a> finding Russian wealth distribution so much more extreme than other countries studied it "deserves to be placed in a separate category."<sup id="cite_ref-pbs_172-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pbs-172">[165]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-CSRIGWR_173-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CSRIGWR-173">[166]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Energy">Energy</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_Russia" title="Energy in Russia">Energy in Russia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power_in_Russia" title="Nuclear power in Russia">Nuclear power in Russia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Russia_in_the_European_energy_sector" title="Russia in the European energy sector">Russia in the European energy sector</a>
      </div>
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Electricity_sector_in_Russia" title="Electricity sector in Russia">Electricity sector in Russia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy_in_Russia" title="Renewable energy in Russia">Renewable energy in Russia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Hydroelectricity_in_Russia" title="Hydroelectricity in Russia">Hydroelectricity in Russia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:RF_NG_pipestoEU.gif" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/RF_NG_pipestoEU.gif/220px-RF_NG_pipestoEU.gif" decoding="async" width="220" height="282" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/RF_NG_pipestoEU.gif/330px-RF_NG_pipestoEU.gif 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/RF_NG_pipestoEU.gif/440px-RF_NG_pipestoEU.gif 2x" data-file-width="590" data-file-height="757"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:RF_NG_pipestoEU.gif" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Russia is a major <a href="/wiki/Petroleum" title="Petroleum">oil</a> and <a href="/wiki/Natural_gas" title="Natural gas">gas</a> supplier to the rest of Europe.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Russia has been frequently described as an <a href="/wiki/Energy_superpower" title="Energy superpower">energy superpower</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174">[167]</a></sup> with the world's largest <a href="/wiki/Natural_gas_reserves" class="mw-redirect" title="Natural gas reserves">natural gas reserves</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-175" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-175">[168]</a></sup> the second-largest <a href="/wiki/Coal_reserves" class="mw-redirect" title="Coal reserves">coal reserves</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-176" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-176">[169]</a></sup> the eighth-largest <a href="/wiki/Oil_reserves" title="Oil reserves">oil reserves</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177">[170]</a></sup> and the largest <a href="/wiki/Oil_shale_reserves" title="Oil shale reserves">oil shale reserves</a> in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178">[171]</a></sup> The country is the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_natural_gas_exports" title="List of countries by natural gas exports">leading natural gas exporter</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179">[172]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_natural_gas_production" title="List of countries by natural gas production">second-largest natural gas producer</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-cia-gas_180-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-gas-180">[173]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_oil_exports" title="List of countries by oil exports">second-largest oil exporter</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181">[174]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_oil_production" title="List of countries by oil production">third-largest oil producer</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182">[175]</a></sup> Fossil fuels cause most of the <a href="/wiki/Greenhouse_gas_emissions_by_Russia" title="Greenhouse gas emissions by Russia">greenhouse gas emissions by Russia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-183" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-183">[176]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Russia is the fourth-largest <a href="/wiki/Electricity_producer" class="mw-redirect" title="Electricity producer">electricity producer</a> in the world,<sup id="cite_ref-184" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-184">[177]</a></sup> and the ninth-largest <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy_producer" class="mw-redirect" title="Renewable energy producer">renewable energy producer</a> in 2019.<sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185">[178]</a></sup> It was the first country to develop civilian nuclear power and to construct the world's <a href="/wiki/First_nuclear_power_plant" class="mw-redirect" title="First nuclear power plant">first nuclear power plant</a>. In 2019, the country was the fourth-largest <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power_by_country" title="Nuclear power by country">nuclear energy producer</a> in the world; nuclear generated 20% of the country's electricity.<sup id="cite_ref-186" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-186">[179]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Agriculture_and_fishery">Agriculture and fishery</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_Russia" title="Agriculture in Russia">Agriculture in Russia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fishing_industry_in_Russia" title="Fishing industry in Russia">Fishing industry in Russia</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Russia has the <a href="/wiki/Land_use_statistics_by_country" title="Land use statistics by country">fourth-largest cultivated area</a> in the world, at 1,237,294 square kilometres (477,722&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi); possessing 7.4% of the world's total <a href="/wiki/Arable_land" title="Arable land">arable land</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-187" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-187">[180]</a></sup> It is the third-largest grain exporter;<sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188">[181]</a></sup> and is the top producer of <a href="/wiki/Barley" title="Barley">barley</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buckwheat" title="Buckwheat">buckwheat</a> and <a href="/wiki/Oats" class="mw-redirect" title="Oats">oats</a>, and one of the largest producers and exporters of <a href="/wiki/Rye" title="Rye">rye</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Sunflower_seed" title="Sunflower seed">sunflower seed</a>. Since 2016, Russia is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_wheat_exports" title="List of countries by wheat exports">largest exporter of wheat</a> in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-189" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-189">[182]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>While large farms concentrate mainly on grain production and <a href="/wiki/Animal_husbandry" title="Animal husbandry">animal husbandry</a>, while small private <a href="/wiki/Household_plot" title="Household plot">household plots</a> produce most of the country's potatoes, vegetables and fruits.<sup id="cite_ref-190" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-190">[183]</a></sup> Russia is the home to the finest <a href="/wiki/Caviar" title="Caviar">caviar</a> in the world;<sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191">[184]</a></sup> and maintains one of the <a href="/wiki/Fishing_industry_by_country" title="Fishing industry by country">world's largest fishing fleets</a>, ranking sixth in the world in tonnage of fish caught; capturing 4,773,413 tons of fish in 2018.<sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192">[185]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Infrastructure">Infrastructure</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Russia" title="Transport in Russia">Transport in Russia</a>, <a href="/wiki/History_of_rail_transport_in_Russia" title="History of rail transport in Russia">History of rail transport in Russia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Rail_transport_in_Russia" title="Rail transport in Russia">Rail transport in Russia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:VL_85-022_container_train.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/VL_85-022_container_train.jpg/220px-VL_85-022_container_train.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="157" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/VL_85-022_container_train.jpg/330px-VL_85-022_container_train.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/VL_85-022_container_train.jpg/440px-VL_85-022_container_train.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1154" data-file-height="825"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:VL_85-022_container_train.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Trans-Siberian_Railway" title="Trans-Siberian Railway">Trans-Siberian Railway</a>, the longest railway-line in the world, as seen across the coast of Lake Baikal.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Railway transport in Russia is mostly under the control of the state-run <a href="/wiki/Russian_Railways" title="Russian Railways">Russian Railways</a> monopoly. The total length of common-used railway tracks exceeds 85,500&nbsp;km (53,127&nbsp;mi),<sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193">[186]</a></sup> second only to the United States. The most renowned railway in Russia is the <a href="/wiki/Trans-Siberian_Railway" title="Trans-Siberian Railway">Trans-Siberian Railway</a>, the longest railway-line in the world. As of 2016<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Russia&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, Russia had <a href="/wiki/Roads_by_country" class="mw-redirect" title="Roads by country">1,452.2&nbsp;km of roads</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194">[187]</a></sup> and its road density is the lowest among the <a href="/wiki/BRICS" title="BRICS">BRICS</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195">[188]</a></sup> Much of Russia's inland waterways, which <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_waterways_length" title="List of countries by waterways length">total 102,000&nbsp;km (63,380&nbsp;mi)</a>, are made up of natural rivers or lakes. Among Russia's 1,216 airports,<sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196">[189]</a></sup> the busiest are <a href="/wiki/Sheremetyevo" class="mw-redirect" title="Sheremetyevo">Sheremetyevo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Domodedovo_International_Airport" class="mw-redirect" title="Domodedovo International Airport">Domodedovo</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Vnukovo_International_Airport" title="Vnukovo International Airport">Vnukovo</a> in Moscow, and <a href="/wiki/Pulkovo_Airport" title="Pulkovo Airport">Pulkovo</a> in Saint Petersburg. </p>
      <p>Major sea ports of Russia include <a href="/wiki/Rostov-on-Don" title="Rostov-on-Don">Rostov-on-Don</a> on the Sea of Azov, <a href="/wiki/Novorossiysk" title="Novorossiysk">Novorossiysk</a> on the Black Sea, <a href="/wiki/Astrakhan" title="Astrakhan">Astrakhan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Makhachkala" title="Makhachkala">Makhachkala</a> on the Caspian, <a href="/wiki/Kaliningrad" title="Kaliningrad">Kaliningrad</a> and St Petersburg on the Baltic, <a href="/wiki/Arkhangelsk" title="Arkhangelsk">Arkhangelsk</a> on the White Sea, <a href="/wiki/Murmansk" title="Murmansk">Murmansk</a> on the Barents Sea, <a href="/wiki/Petropavlovsk-Kamchatsky" title="Petropavlovsk-Kamchatsky">Petropavlovsk-Kamchatsky</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vladivostok" title="Vladivostok">Vladivostok</a> on the Pacific Ocean. The world's only fleet of <a href="/wiki/Nuclear-powered_icebreaker" title="Nuclear-powered icebreaker">nuclear-powered icebreakers</a> advances the economic exploitation of the Arctic <a href="/wiki/Continental_shelf_of_Russia" title="Continental shelf of Russia">continental shelf of Russia</a> and the development of sea trade through the <a href="/wiki/Northern_Sea_Route" title="Northern Sea Route">Northern Sea Route</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Science_and_technology">Science and technology</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_Russian_inventions_and_technology_records" class="mw-redirect" title="Timeline of Russian inventions and technology records">Timeline of Russian inventions and technology records</a>, <a href="/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_Russia" title="Science and technology in Russia">Science and technology in Russia</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_Russian_scientists" title="List of Russian scientists">List of Russian scientists</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Russian_inventors" title="List of Russian inventors">List of Russian inventors</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:M.V._Lomonosov_by_L.Miropolskiy_after_G.C.Prenner_(1787,_RAN).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/M.V._Lomonosov_by_L.Miropolskiy_after_G.C.Prenner_%281787%2C_RAN%29.jpg/170px-M.V._Lomonosov_by_L.Miropolskiy_after_G.C.Prenner_%281787%2C_RAN%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="228" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/M.V._Lomonosov_by_L.Miropolskiy_after_G.C.Prenner_%281787%2C_RAN%29.jpg/255px-M.V._Lomonosov_by_L.Miropolskiy_after_G.C.Prenner_%281787%2C_RAN%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/M.V._Lomonosov_by_L.Miropolskiy_after_G.C.Prenner_%281787%2C_RAN%29.jpg/340px-M.V._Lomonosov_by_L.Miropolskiy_after_G.C.Prenner_%281787%2C_RAN%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="597" data-file-height="800"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:M.V._Lomonosov_by_L.Miropolskiy_after_G.C.Prenner_(1787,_RAN).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Lomonosov" title="Mikhail Lomonosov">Mikhail Lomonosov</a> (1711â1765), <a href="/wiki/Polymath" title="Polymath">polymath</a> scientist, inventor, poet and artist
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Russia is a leading nation in <a href="/wiki/Scientific_method" title="Scientific method">scientific research</a>; its <a href="/wiki/Research_and_development" title="Research and development">research and development</a> budget is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_research_and_development_spending" title="List of countries by research and development spending">ninth-highest</a> in the world, with an expenditure of approximately 422 billion rubles on domestic research and development.<sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197">[190]</a></sup> In 2019, Russia was ranked tenth worldwide in the number of scientific publications.<sup id="cite_ref-198" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-198">[191]</a></sup> Since 1904, <a href="/wiki/List_of_Nobel_laureates_by_country" title="List of Nobel laureates by country">Nobel Prize</a> were awarded to twenty-six Russian and Soviet people in <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Physics" title="Nobel Prize in Physics">physics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Chemistry" title="Nobel Prize in Chemistry">chemistry</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_medicine" class="mw-redirect" title="Nobel Prize in medicine">medicine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Memorial_Prize_in_Economic_Sciences" title="Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences">economy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature" title="Nobel Prize in Literature">literature</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Peace_Prize" title="Nobel Peace Prize">peace</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199">[192]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Lomonosov" title="Mikhail Lomonosov">Mikhail Lomonosov</a> proposed the law of conservation of matter preceding the <a href="/wiki/Energy_conservation_law" class="mw-redirect" title="Energy conservation law">energy conservation law</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-mes_200-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mes-200">[193]</a></sup> Since the time of <a href="/wiki/Nikolay_Lobachevsky" class="mw-redirect" title="Nikolay Lobachevsky">Nikolay Lobachevsky</a> (the "<a href="/wiki/Copernicus" class="mw-redirect" title="Copernicus">Copernicus</a> of <a href="/wiki/Geometry" title="Geometry">Geometry</a>" who pioneered the <a href="/wiki/Non-Euclidean_geometry" title="Non-Euclidean geometry">non-Euclidean geometry</a>) and a prominent tutor <a href="/wiki/Pafnuty_Chebyshev" title="Pafnuty Chebyshev">Pafnuty Chebyshev</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Russian_mathematical_school" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian mathematical school">Russian mathematical school</a> became one of the most influential in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201">[194]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Dmitry_Mendeleev" class="mw-redirect" title="Dmitry Mendeleev">Dmitry Mendeleev</a> invented the <a href="/wiki/Periodic_table" title="Periodic table">Periodic table</a>, the main framework of modern <a href="/wiki/Chemistry" title="Chemistry">chemistry</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-mes_200-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mes-200">[193]</a></sup> Nine Soviet/Russian mathematicians were awarded with the <a href="/wiki/Fields_Medal" title="Fields Medal">Fields Medal</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202">[195]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Grigori_Perelman" title="Grigori Perelman">Grigori Perelman</a> was offered the first ever Clay <a href="/wiki/Millennium_Prize_Problems" title="Millennium Prize Problems">Millennium Prize Problems</a> Award for his final proof of the <a href="/wiki/Poincar%C3%A9_conjecture" title="PoincarÃ© conjecture">PoincarÃ© conjecture</a> in 2002.<sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203">[196]</a></sup> Russian discoveries and inventions include the <a href="/wiki/Incandescent_light_bulb" title="Incandescent light bulb">electric filament lamp</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Aircraft" title="Aircraft">aircraft</a>, the safety <a href="/wiki/Parachute" title="Parachute">parachute</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sputnik_1" title="Sputnik 1">sputnik</a>, <a href="/wiki/Radio_receiver" title="Radio receiver">radio receiver</a>, electrical <a href="/wiki/Microscope" title="Microscope">microscope</a>, <a href="/wiki/Color_photography" title="Color photography">colour photos</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-204" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-204">[197]</a></sup> caterpillar tracks, track assembly, electrically powered <a href="/wiki/Railroad_car" title="Railroad car">railway wagons</a>, <a href="/wiki/Video_tape_recorder" title="Video tape recorder">videotape recorder</a>, <a href="/wiki/Helicopter" title="Helicopter">helicopter</a>, <a href="/wiki/Solar_cell" title="Solar cell">solar cell</a>, <a href="/wiki/Transformer" title="Transformer">transformers</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yogurt" title="Yogurt">yogurt</a>, <a href="/wiki/Television" title="Television">television</a>, petrol <a href="/wiki/Cracking_(chemistry)" title="Cracking (chemistry)">cracking</a>, <a href="/wiki/Synthetic_rubber" title="Synthetic rubber">synthetic rubber</a> and <a href="/wiki/Combine_harvester" title="Combine harvester">grain harvester</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-205" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-205">[198]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Mir_on_12_June_1998edit1.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Mir_on_12_June_1998edit1.jpg/220px-Mir_on_12_June_1998edit1.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="211" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Mir_on_12_June_1998edit1.jpg/330px-Mir_on_12_June_1998edit1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Mir_on_12_June_1998edit1.jpg/440px-Mir_on_12_June_1998edit1.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2100" data-file-height="2010"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Mir_on_12_June_1998edit1.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Soviet and Russian <a href="/wiki/Space_station" title="Space station">space station</a> <a href="/wiki/Mir" title="Mir">Mir</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Roscosmos" title="Roscosmos">Roscosmos</a> is Russia's national space agency; while Russian achievements in the field of <a href="/wiki/Space_technology" title="Space technology">space technology</a> and <a href="/wiki/Space_exploration" title="Space exploration">space exploration</a> are traced back to <a href="/wiki/Konstantin_Tsiolkovsky" title="Konstantin Tsiolkovsky">Konstantin Tsiolkovsky</a>, the father of theoretical <a href="/wiki/Astronautics" title="Astronautics">astronautics</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-206" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-206">[199]</a></sup> His works had inspired leading Soviet rocket engineers, such as <a href="/wiki/Sergey_Korolyov" class="mw-redirect" title="Sergey Korolyov">Sergey Korolyov</a>, <a href="/wiki/Valentin_Glushko" title="Valentin Glushko">Valentin Glushko</a>, and many others who contributed to the success of the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_space_program" title="Soviet space program">Soviet space program</a> in the early stages of the <a href="/wiki/Space_Race" title="Space Race">Space Race</a> and beyond. </p>
      <p>In 1957, the first Earth-orbiting artificial <a href="/wiki/Satellite" title="Satellite">satellite</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/Sputnik_1" title="Sputnik 1">Sputnik&nbsp;1</a></i>, was launched; in 1961 the first human trip into space was successfully made by <a href="/wiki/Yuri_Gagarin" title="Yuri Gagarin">Yuri Gagarin</a>. Many other Soviet and Russian <a href="/wiki/Space_exploration_records" class="mw-redirect" title="Space exploration records">space exploration records</a> ensued, including the first <a href="/wiki/Spacewalk" class="mw-redirect" title="Spacewalk">spacewalk</a> performed by <a href="/wiki/Alexei_Leonov" title="Alexei Leonov">Alexei Leonov</a>, <a href="/wiki/Luna_9" title="Luna 9">Luna&nbsp;9</a> was the first spacecraft to land on the <a href="/wiki/Moon" title="Moon">Moon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zond_5" title="Zond 5">Zond 5</a> brought the first Earthlings (two tortoises and other life forms) to circumnavigate the Moon, <a href="/wiki/Venera_7" title="Venera 7">Venera&nbsp;7</a> was the first to land on another planet (<a href="/wiki/Venus" title="Venus">Venus</a>), <a href="/wiki/Mars_3" title="Mars 3">Mars&nbsp;3</a> then the first to land on <a href="/wiki/Mars" title="Mars">Mars</a>, the first <a href="/wiki/Space_exploration_rover" class="mw-redirect" title="Space exploration rover">space exploration rover</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Lunokhod-1" class="mw-redirect" title="Lunokhod-1">Lunokhod 1</a></i>, and the first <a href="/wiki/Space_station" title="Space station">space station</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Salyut_1" title="Salyut 1">Salyut&nbsp;1</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Mir" title="Mir">Mir</a></i>. Russia is the largest satellite launcher.<sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207">[200]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Russia has completed the <a href="/wiki/GLONASS" title="GLONASS">GLONASS</a> <a href="/wiki/Satellite_navigation_system" class="mw-redirect" title="Satellite navigation system">satellite navigation system</a>, and is developing its own <a href="/wiki/Sukhoi_PAK_FA" class="mw-redirect" title="Sukhoi PAK FA">fifth-generation jet fighter</a> and constructing the first serial <a href="/wiki/Mobile_nuclear_plant" class="mw-redirect" title="Mobile nuclear plant">mobile nuclear plant</a> in the world. <a href="/wiki/Soyuz_(rocket_family)" title="Soyuz (rocket family)">Soyuz rockets</a> are the only provider of transport for astronauts at the <a href="/wiki/International_Space_Station" title="International Space Station">International Space Station</a>. <a href="/wiki/Luna-Glob" title="Luna-Glob">Luna-Glob</a> is a Russian Moon exploration programme, with first planned mission launch in 2021. Roscosmos is also developing the <a href="/wiki/Orel_spacecraft" class="mw-redirect" title="Orel spacecraft">Orel spacecraft</a>, to replace the aging Soyuz, it could also conduct mission to lunar orbit as early as 2026.<sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208">[201]</a></sup> In February 2019, it was announced that Russia is intending to conduct its first crewed mission to land on the Moon in 2031.<sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-209">[202]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">Tourism</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Russia" title="Tourism in Russia">Tourism in Russia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Grand_Cascade_in_Peterhof_01.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Grand_Cascade_in_Peterhof_01.jpg/220px-Grand_Cascade_in_Peterhof_01.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Grand_Cascade_in_Peterhof_01.jpg/330px-Grand_Cascade_in_Peterhof_01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Grand_Cascade_in_Peterhof_01.jpg/440px-Grand_Cascade_in_Peterhof_01.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4200" data-file-height="2800"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Grand_Cascade_in_Peterhof_01.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Peterhof_Palace" title="Peterhof Palace">Peterhof Palace</a> in Saint Petersburg, a <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">World Heritage Site</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>According to a <a href="/wiki/World_Tourism_Organization" title="World Tourism Organization">UNWTO</a> report, Russia is the sixteenth-most visited country in the world, and the tenth-most visited country in Europe, as of 2018, with 24.6 million visits.<sup id="cite_ref-unwto_210-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-unwto-210">[203]</a></sup> Russia is ranked 39th in the Travel and Tourism Competitiveness Report 2019.<sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211">[204]</a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/Federal_Agency_for_Tourism_(Russia)" title="Federal Agency for Tourism (Russia)">Federal Agency for Tourism</a>, the number of inbound trips of foreign citizens to Russia amounted to 24.4 million in 2019.<sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212">[205]</a></sup> Russia's international tourism receipts in 2018 amounted to $11.6 billion.<sup id="cite_ref-unwto_210-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-unwto-210">[203]</a></sup> In 2020, tourism accounted for about 4% of country's GDP.<sup id="cite_ref-213" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-213">[206]</a></sup> Major tourist routes in Russia include a journey around the <a href="/wiki/Golden_Ring_(Russia)" class="mw-redirect" title="Golden Ring (Russia)">Golden Ring</a> <a href="/wiki/Theme_route" class="mw-redirect" title="Theme route">theme route</a> of ancient cities, cruises on the big rivers like the <a href="/wiki/Volga" title="Volga">Volga</a>, and journeys on the famous <a href="/wiki/Trans-Siberian_Railway" title="Trans-Siberian Railway">Trans-Siberian Railway</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-214" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-214">[207]</a></sup> Russia's most visited and popular landmarks include <a href="/wiki/Red_Square" title="Red Square">Red Square</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Peterhof_Palace" title="Peterhof Palace">Peterhof Palace</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Kazan_Kremlin" title="Kazan Kremlin">Kazan Kremlin</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Trinity_Lavra_of_St._Sergius" title="Trinity Lavra of St. Sergius">Trinity Lavra of St. Sergius</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lake_Baikal" title="Lake Baikal">Lake Baikal</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-215" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-215">[208]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Russia" title="Demographics of Russia">Demographics of Russia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Russians" title="Russians">Russians</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Russia had a population of 142.8 million according to the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Census_(2010)" title="Russian Census (2010)">2010 census</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-2010Census_216-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2010Census-216">[209]</a></sup> which rose to 146.7 million as of 2020.<sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217">[210]</a></sup> It is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_European_countries_by_population" title="List of European countries by population">most populous country</a> in Europe, and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_population" title="List of countries and dependencies by population">ninth-most populous country</a> in the world, its <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_population_density" class="mw-redirect" title="List of countries by population density">population density</a> stands at 9 inhabitants per square kilometre (23 per square mile). The overall <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_life_expectancy" title="List of countries by life expectancy">life expectancy in Russia</a> at birth is 72.4 years (66.9 years for males and 77.6 years for females).<sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218">[211]</a></sup> Since the 1990s, Russia's <a href="/wiki/Death_rate" class="mw-redirect" title="Death rate">death rate</a> has exceeded its <a href="/wiki/Birth_rate" title="Birth rate">birth rate</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219">[212]</a></sup> As of 2018, the <a href="/wiki/Total_fertility_rate" title="Total fertility rate">total fertility rate</a> (TFR) across Russia was estimated to be 1.82 born per woman,<sup id="cite_ref-gks.ru-tfr_220-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gks.ru-tfr-220">[213]</a></sup> one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_sovereign_states_and_dependencies_by_total_fertility_rate" title="List of sovereign states and dependencies by total fertility rate">lowest fertility rates in the world</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-auto1_221-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto1-221">[214]</a></sup> below the replacement rate of 2.1, and considerably below the high of 7.44 children born per woman in 1908.<sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222">[215]</a></sup> Subsequently, the country has one of the oldest populations in the world, with an average age of 40.3 years.<sup id="cite_ref-auto1_221-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto1-221">[214]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Nevertheless, Russia's overall birth rate is higher than that of most European countries (10.8 births per 1000 people in 2020,<sup id="cite_ref-gks.ru_223-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gks.ru-223">[216]</a></sup> compared to the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">EU</a> average of 9.5 per 1000),<sup id="cite_ref-EU1_224-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EU1-224">[217]</a></sup> though its death rate is also substantially higher (in 2020, Russia's death rate was 11.1 per 1000 people,<sup id="cite_ref-gks.ru_223-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gks.ru-223">[216]</a></sup> compared to the EU average of 10.7 per 1000).<sup id="cite_ref-EU1_224-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EU1-224">[217]</a></sup> In 2009, it recorded annual population growth for the first time in fifteen yearsâSince the 2010s, Russia has seen increased population growth due to declining <a href="/wiki/Death_rates" class="mw-redirect" title="Death rates">death rates</a>, increased <a href="/wiki/Birth_rates" class="mw-redirect" title="Birth rates">birth rates</a> and increased <a href="/wiki/Immigration" title="Immigration">immigration</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-gks.ru_223-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gks.ru-223">[216]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Russia is a <a href="/wiki/Multinational_state" title="Multinational state">multinational state</a>; home to over 193 ethnic groups. In the 2010 Census; out of its total population of 142.8 million,<sup id="cite_ref-2010Census_216-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2010Census-216">[209]</a></sup> 80.9%, or 111 million, were ethnic <a href="/wiki/Russians" title="Russians">Russians</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-ethnicgroups_225-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ethnicgroups-225">[218]</a></sup> while rest of the 19% of the population were minorities.<sup id="cite_ref-perepis-2010.ru_5-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-perepis-2010.ru-5">[4]</a></sup> Around 84.93% of the Russian population belonged to the European ethnic groups in 2010,<sup id="cite_ref-perepis-2010.ru_5-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-perepis-2010.ru-5">[4]</a></sup> of which the vast majority were <a href="/wiki/Slavs" title="Slavs">Slavs</a>, with minorities of <a href="/wiki/Germanic_peoples" title="Germanic peoples">Germanic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Baltic-Finnic_peoples" class="mw-redirect" title="Baltic-Finnic peoples">Baltic-Finnic</a> and other peoples. There are <a href="/wiki/Republics_of_Russia" title="Republics of Russia">22 republics</a> in Russia, designated to have their own ethnicities, cultures, and languages. In 13 of them, ethnic Russians <a href="/wiki/Republics_of_Russia#Demographics_trend" title="Republics of Russia">consist a minority</a>. According to the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>, Russia's <a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_Russia" title="Immigration to Russia">immigrant population</a> is the third-largest in the world, numbering over 11.6 million;<sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226">[219]</a></sup> most of which are from <a href="/wiki/Post-Soviet_states" title="Post-Soviet states">post-Soviet states</a>, mainly <a href="/wiki/Ukrainians_in_Russia" title="Ukrainians in Russia">Ukrainians</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-227" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-227">[220]</a></sup> </p> 
      <table class="navbox"> 
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <th colspan="10" class="navbox-title">
          <div style="float:right; width:6em; height:2.6em">

           </ul>
          </div>

           <span style="font-size:110%;">Largest cities or towns in Russia</span>
           <br>
           <div style="display:inline;font-weight:normal;">

           </div>
          </div> </th>
        </tr>

         <th><a href="/wiki/Federal_subjects_of_Russia" title="Federal subjects of Russia">Federal subject</a> </th> 
         <th><a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Russia_by_population" class="mw-redirect" title="List of cities in Russia by population">Pop.</a> </th> 
         <th><a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Russia_by_population" class="mw-redirect" title="List of cities in Russia by population">Rank</a> </th> 
         <th><a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Russia" class="mw-redirect" title="List of cities in Russia">Name</a> </th> 
         <th><a href="/wiki/Federal_subjects_of_Russia" title="Federal subjects of Russia">Federal subject</a> </th> 
         <th><a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Russia_by_population" class="mw-redirect" title="List of cities in Russia by population">Pop.</a></th> 
         <th> </th>
        </tr> 
        <tr>

      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Language">Language</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Russian_language" title="Russian language">Russian language</a> and <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Russia" title="Languages of Russia">Languages of Russia</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:352px;max-width:352px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="theader">
          Minority languages across Russia
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:147px;max-width:147px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:90px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Linguistic_map_of_the_Altaic,_Turkic_and_Uralic_languages_(en).png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Linguistic_map_of_the_Altaic%2C_Turkic_and_Uralic_languages_%28en%29.png/145px-Linguistic_map_of_the_Altaic%2C_Turkic_and_Uralic_languages_%28en%29.png" decoding="async" width="145" height="91" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Linguistic_map_of_the_Altaic%2C_Turkic_and_Uralic_languages_%28en%29.png/218px-Linguistic_map_of_the_Altaic%2C_Turkic_and_Uralic_languages_%28en%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Linguistic_map_of_the_Altaic%2C_Turkic_and_Uralic_languages_%28en%29.png/290px-Linguistic_map_of_the_Altaic%2C_Turkic_and_Uralic_languages_%28en%29.png 2x" data-file-width="3245" data-file-height="2036"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption text-align-center">
           <span style="font-family:sans-serif;font-size:100%;color:black;background-color:transparent;;">Distribution of the <a href="/wiki/Uralic_languages" title="Uralic languages">Uralic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Altaic_languages" title="Altaic languages">Altaic</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Yukaghir_languages" title="Yukaghir languages">Yukaghir languages</a></span>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:117px;max-width:117px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:90px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Fenno-Ugrian_languages.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Fenno-Ugrian_languages.png/115px-Fenno-Ugrian_languages.png" decoding="async" width="115" height="91" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Fenno-Ugrian_languages.png/173px-Fenno-Ugrian_languages.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Fenno-Ugrian_languages.png/230px-Fenno-Ugrian_languages.png 2x" data-file-width="1025" data-file-height="808"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption text-align-center">
           <span style="font-family:sans-serif;font-size:100%;color:black;background-color:transparent;;">Geographical distribution of the <a href="/wiki/Finno-Ugric_peoples" title="Finno-Ugric peoples">Finno-Ugric</a> and <a href="/wiki/Samoyedic_peoples" title="Samoyedic peoples">Samoyedic peoples</a></span>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:82px;max-width:82px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:90px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Caucasus-ethnic_en.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Caucasus-ethnic_en.svg/80px-Caucasus-ethnic_en.svg.png" decoding="async" width="80" height="91" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Caucasus-ethnic_en.svg/120px-Caucasus-ethnic_en.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Caucasus-ethnic_en.svg/160px-Caucasus-ethnic_en.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="977" data-file-height="1111"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption text-align-center">
           <span style="font-family:sans-serif;font-size:100%;color:black;background-color:transparent;;"><a href="/wiki/Languages_of_the_Caucasus" title="Languages of the Caucasus">Ethnolinguistic groups</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Caucasus" title="Caucasus">Caucasus</a></span>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Russia's <a href="/wiki/Official_language" title="Official language">official language</a> is <a href="/wiki/Russian_language" title="Russian language">Russian</a>. However, Russia's 193 minority ethnic groups speak over 100 languages.<sup id="cite_ref-britannica_241-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-britannica-241">[234]</a></sup> According to the 2002 Census, 142.6&nbsp;million people speak Russian, followed by <a href="/wiki/Tatar_language" title="Tatar language">Tatar</a> with 5.3&nbsp;million, and <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_language" title="Ukrainian language">Ukrainian</a> with 1.8&nbsp;million speakers.<sup id="cite_ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242">[235]</a></sup> The constitution gives the individual republics of the country the right to establish their own state languages in addition to Russian.<sup id="cite_ref-243" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-243">[236]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Russian is the most spoken <a href="/wiki/Native_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Native language">native language</a> in Europe, the most geographically widespread language of Eurasia, as well as the most widely spoken <a href="/wiki/Slavic_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Slavic language">Slavic language</a> in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244">[237]</a></sup> It belongs to the <a href="/wiki/Indo-European_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Indo-European language">Indo-European language</a> family, is one of the living members of the <a href="/wiki/East_Slavic_languages" title="East Slavic languages">East Slavic languages</a>, and is among the larger <a href="/wiki/Balto-Slavic_languages" title="Balto-Slavic languages">Balto-Slavic languages</a>. </p>
      <p>Russian is the second-most used language on the <a href="/wiki/Internet" title="Internet">Internet</a> after English,<sup id="cite_ref-245" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-245">[238]</a></sup> one of two official languages aboard the <a href="/wiki/International_Space_Station" title="International Space Station">International Space Station</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-246" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-246">[239]</a></sup> and is one of the six <a href="/wiki/Official_languages_of_the_United_Nations" title="Official languages of the United Nations">official languages of the United Nations</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-247" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-247">[240]</a></sup> 35 languages are officially recognised in Russia in various regions by local governments: </p> 
      <table class="collapsible collapsed" style="border:2px solid #bdb76b; float:center; margin:5px auto 0 auto;"> 
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <th style="background:#f5f5f5; padding:5px;">Officially recognized minority languages in Russia </th>
        </tr>

         <th>Language</th> 
         <th>Language family</th> 
         <th>Federal subject(s)</th> 
         <th>Source </th>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/Abaza_language" title="Abaza language">Abaza</a></td> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/Northwest_Caucasian_languages" title="Northwest Caucasian languages">Northwest Caucasian</a></td> 
         <td><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Flag_of_Karachay-Cherkessia.svg/23px-Flag_of_Karachay-Cherkessia.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="12" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Flag_of_Karachay-Cherkessia.svg/35px-Flag_of_Karachay-Cherkessia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Flag_of_Karachay-Cherkessia.svg/46px-Flag_of_Karachay-Cherkessia.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="600">&nbsp;</span><a href="/wiki/Karachay-Cherkessia" title="Karachay-Cherkessia">Karachay-Cherkessia</a></td> 
         <td><sup id="cite_ref-KarCherk_248-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-KarCherk-248">[241]</a></sup> </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/Adyghe_language" title="Adyghe language">Adyghe</a></td> 
         <td>Northwest Caucasian</td> 
         <td><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Flag_of_Adygea.svg/23px-Flag_of_Adygea.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="12" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Flag_of_Adygea.svg/35px-Flag_of_Adygea.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Flag_of_Adygea.svg/46px-Flag_of_Adygea.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="600" data-file-height="300">&nbsp;</span><a href="/wiki/Adygea" title="Adygea">Adygea</a></td> 
         <td><sup id="cite_ref-249" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-249">[242]</a></sup> </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/Altai_language" title="Altai language">Altai</a></td> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/Turkic_languages" title="Turkic languages">Turkic</a></td>

         <td><a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_language" title="Ukrainian language">Ukrainian</a></td>
