         <td><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Flag_of_Crimea.svg/23px-Flag_of_Crimea.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="12" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Flag_of_Crimea.svg/35px-Flag_of_Crimea.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Flag_of_Crimea.svg/46px-Flag_of_Crimea.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="600">&nbsp;</span><a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Crimea" title="Republic of Crimea">Republic of Crimea</a><sup id="cite_ref-crimealanguages_256-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-crimealanguages-256">[h]</a></sup></td> 
         <td><sup id="cite_ref-Crimea_257-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Crimea-257">[249]</a></sup> </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/Yakut_language" title="Yakut language">Yakut</a></td> 
         <td>Turkic</td> 
         <td><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Flag_of_Sakha.svg/23px-Flag_of_Sakha.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="12" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Flag_of_Sakha.svg/35px-Flag_of_Sakha.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Flag_of_Sakha.svg/46px-Flag_of_Sakha.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="600">&nbsp;</span><a href="/wiki/Yakutia" class="mw-redirect" title="Yakutia">Sakha Republic</a></td> 
         <td><sup id="cite_ref-269" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-269">[261]</a></sup> </td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Russia" title="Religion in Russia">Religion in Russia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:%D0%A5%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BC_%D0%A5%D1%80%D0%B8%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B0_%D0%A1%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%81%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%B5%D0%BB%D1%8F._%D0%92%D0%B8%D0%B4_%D1%81%D0%BE_%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%BD%D1%8B_%D0%92%D0%BE%D0%BB%D1%85%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%B8._%E2%80%94_Cathedral_of_Christ_the_Saviour.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/%D0%A5%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BC_%D0%A5%D1%80%D0%B8%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B0_%D0%A1%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%81%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%B5%D0%BB%D1%8F._%D0%92%D0%B8%D0%B4_%D1%81%D0%BE_%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%BD%D1%8B_%D0%92%D0%BE%D0%BB%D1%85%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%B8._%E2%80%94_Cathedral_of_Christ_the_Saviour.jpg/220px-%D0%A5%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BC_%D0%A5%D1%80%D0%B8%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B0_%D0%A1%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%81%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%B5%D0%BB%D1%8F._%D0%92%D0%B8%D0%B4_%D1%81%D0%BE_%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%BD%D1%8B_%D0%92%D0%BE%D0%BB%D1%85%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%B8._%E2%80%94_Cathedral_of_Christ_the_Saviour.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/%D0%A5%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BC_%D0%A5%D1%80%D0%B8%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B0_%D0%A1%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%81%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%B5%D0%BB%D1%8F._%D0%92%D0%B8%D0%B4_%D1%81%D0%BE_%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%BD%D1%8B_%D0%92%D0%BE%D0%BB%D1%85%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%B8._%E2%80%94_Cathedral_of_Christ_the_Saviour.jpg/330px-%D0%A5%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BC_%D0%A5%D1%80%D0%B8%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B0_%D0%A1%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%81%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%B5%D0%BB%D1%8F._%D0%92%D0%B8%D0%B4_%D1%81%D0%BE_%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%BD%D1%8B_%D0%92%D0%BE%D0%BB%D1%85%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%B8._%E2%80%94_Cathedral_of_Christ_the_Saviour.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/%D0%A5%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BC_%D0%A5%D1%80%D0%B8%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B0_%D0%A1%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%81%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%B5%D0%BB%D1%8F._%D0%92%D0%B8%D0%B4_%D1%81%D0%BE_%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%BD%D1%8B_%D0%92%D0%BE%D0%BB%D1%85%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%B8._%E2%80%94_Cathedral_of_Christ_the_Saviour.jpg/440px-%D0%A5%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BC_%D0%A5%D1%80%D0%B8%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B0_%D0%A1%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%81%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%B5%D0%BB%D1%8F._%D0%92%D0%B8%D0%B4_%D1%81%D0%BE_%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%BD%D1%8B_%D0%92%D0%BE%D0%BB%D1%85%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%B8._%E2%80%94_Cathedral_of_Christ_the_Saviour.jpg 2x" data-file-width="6000" data-file-height="4000"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:%D0%A5%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BC_%D0%A5%D1%80%D0%B8%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B0_%D0%A1%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%81%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%B5%D0%BB%D1%8F._%D0%92%D0%B8%D0%B4_%D1%81%D0%BE_%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%BD%D1%8B_%D0%92%D0%BE%D0%BB%D1%85%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%B8._%E2%80%94_Cathedral_of_Christ_the_Saviour.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Cathedral_of_Christ_the_Savior" class="mw-redirect" title="Cathedral of Christ the Savior">Cathedral of Christ the Savior</a> in Moscow
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Russia is a <a href="/wiki/Secular_state" title="Secular state">secular state</a> by constitution, and its largest religion is <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a>; it has the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodoxy_by_country" title="Eastern Orthodoxy by country">largest Eastern Orthodox population</a> in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-270" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-270">[262]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-271" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-271">[263]</a></sup> As of a different sociological surveys on religious adherence, from 41% to over 80% of the total population of Russia adhere to the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Orthodox_Church" title="Russian Orthodox Church">Russian Orthodox Church</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ArenaAtlas2012_272-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ArenaAtlas2012-272">[264]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Ogonek_273-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ogonek-273">[265]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-274" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-274">[266]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 2017, a survey made by the <a href="/wiki/Pew_Research_Center" title="Pew Research Center">Pew Research Center</a> showed that 73% of Russians declared themselves Christiansâincluding 71% <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox" class="mw-redirect" title="Eastern Orthodox">Orthodox</a>, 1% <a href="/wiki/Catholic" class="mw-redirect" title="Catholic">Catholic</a>, and 2% Other Christians, while 15% were <a href="/wiki/Irreligion" title="Irreligion">unaffiliated</a>, 10% were <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Muslims</a>, and 1% were from other religions.<sup id="cite_ref-Pew2017_6-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pew2017-6">[5]</a></sup> According to various reports, the proportion of not religious people in Russia is between 16% and 48% of the population.<sup id="cite_ref-275" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-275">[267]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Islam_in_Russia" title="Islam in Russia">Islam</a> is the second-largest religion in Russia.<sup id="cite_ref-276" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-276">[268]</a></sup> It is the traditional or predominant religion amongst the <a href="/wiki/Peoples_of_the_Caucasus" title="Peoples of the Caucasus">Caucasian ethnicities</a> of the North Caucasus, and amongst some <a href="/wiki/Turkic_peoples" title="Turkic peoples">Turkic peoples</a> of the Volga Region. <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Russia" title="Buddhism in Russia">Buddhism</a> is traditional in three republics of Russia: <a href="/wiki/Buryatia" title="Buryatia">Buryatia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tuva" title="Tuva">Tuva</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Kalmykia" title="Kalmykia">Kalmykia</a>, the latter being the only region in Europe where Buddhism is the most practiced religion.<sup id="cite_ref-277" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-277">[269]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Russia" title="Education in Russia">Education in Russia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:%D0%9C%D0%93%D0%A3,_%D0%B2%D0%B8%D0%B4_%D1%81_%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B7%D0%B4%D1%83%D1%85%D0%B0.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/%D0%9C%D0%93%D0%A3%2C_%D0%B2%D0%B8%D0%B4_%D1%81_%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B7%D0%B4%D1%83%D1%85%D0%B0.jpg/220px-%D0%9C%D0%93%D0%A3%2C_%D0%B2%D0%B8%D0%B4_%D1%81_%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B7%D0%B4%D1%83%D1%85%D0%B0.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/%D0%9C%D0%93%D0%A3%2C_%D0%B2%D0%B8%D0%B4_%D1%81_%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B7%D0%B4%D1%83%D1%85%D0%B0.jpg/330px-%D0%9C%D0%93%D0%A3%2C_%D0%B2%D0%B8%D0%B4_%D1%81_%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B7%D0%B4%D1%83%D1%85%D0%B0.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/%D0%9C%D0%93%D0%A3%2C_%D0%B2%D0%B8%D0%B4_%D1%81_%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B7%D0%B4%D1%83%D1%85%D0%B0.jpg/440px-%D0%9C%D0%93%D0%A3%2C_%D0%B2%D0%B8%D0%B4_%D1%81_%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B7%D0%B4%D1%83%D1%85%D0%B0.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3946" data-file-height="2610"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:%D0%9C%D0%93%D0%A3,_%D0%B2%D0%B8%D0%B4_%D1%81_%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B7%D0%B4%D1%83%D1%85%D0%B0.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Moscow_State_University" title="Moscow State University">Moscow State University</a>, the most prestigious educational institution in Russia.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Russia has the highest college-level or higher graduates in terms of percentage of population in the world, at 54%.<sup id="cite_ref-278" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-278">[270]</a></sup> It has a <a href="/wiki/Free_education" title="Free education">free education</a> system, which is guaranteed for all citizens by the constitution.<sup id="cite_ref-279" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-279">[271]</a></sup> Since 1990, the 11-year school education has been introduced. Education in state-owned secondary schools is free. University level education is free, with exceptions. A substantial share of students are enrolled for full pay (many state institutions started to open commercial positions in the last years).<sup id="cite_ref-280" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-280">[272]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The oldest and largest <a href="/wiki/List_of_institutions_of_higher_education_in_Russia" title="List of institutions of higher education in Russia">universities</a> in Russia are <a href="/wiki/Moscow_State_University" title="Moscow State University">Moscow State University</a> and <a href="/wiki/Saint_Petersburg_State_University" title="Saint Petersburg State University">Saint Petersburg State University</a>. In the 2000s, in order to create higher education and research institutions of comparable scale in Russian regions, the government launched a program of establishing federal universities, mostly by merging existing large regional universities and research institutes and providing them with a special funding. These new institutions include the <a href="/wiki/Southern_Federal_University" title="Southern Federal University">Southern Federal University</a>, <a href="/wiki/Siberian_Federal_University" title="Siberian Federal University">Siberian Federal University</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kazan_Volga_Federal_University" class="mw-redirect" title="Kazan Volga Federal University">Kazan Volga Federal University</a>, <a href="/wiki/North-Eastern_Federal_University" title="North-Eastern Federal University">North-Eastern Federal University</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Far_Eastern_Federal_University" title="Far Eastern Federal University">Far Eastern Federal University</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Health">Health</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Healthcare_in_Russia" title="Healthcare in Russia">Healthcare in Russia</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The constitution of Russia guarantees free, <a href="/wiki/Universal_health_care" title="Universal health care">universal health care</a> for all its citizens.<sup id="cite_ref-281" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-281">[273]</a></sup> In practice, however, free health care is partially restricted because of <a href="/wiki/Registration_in_Russia" class="mw-redirect" title="Registration in Russia">mandatory registration</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-282" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-282">[274]</a></sup> Russia has more physicians, hospitals, and health care workers than almost any other country in the world on a per capita basis.<sup id="cite_ref-283" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-283">[275]</a></sup> In the aftermath of the dissolution of the Soviet Union, the health of the Russian population declined as a result of social, economic, and lifestyle changes;<sup id="cite_ref-284" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-284">[276]</a></sup> the trend has been reversed while in the recent years, average life expectancy increased considerably; 6.8 years for males and 4.2 years for females between 2006 and 2018.<sup id="cite_ref-hdr2019_285-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hdr2019-285">[277]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>As of 2018<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Russia&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, the average life expectancy at birth in Russia is 72.4 years (66.9 years for males and 77.6 years for females).<sup id="cite_ref-hdr2019_285-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hdr2019-285">[277]</a></sup> The biggest factor contributing to the relatively low life expectancy for males is a high mortality rate among working-age males; which mostly occurs from preventable causes, including alcohol poisoning, smoking, traffic accidents and violent crime.<sup id="cite_ref-286" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-286">[278]</a></sup> As a result, Russia has one of the world's most female-biased <a href="/wiki/Human_sex_ratio" title="Human sex ratio">sex ratios</a>, with 0.859 males to every female.<sup id="cite_ref-cia_121-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-121">[116]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Russian_culture" title="Russian culture">Russian culture</a>
      </div> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Art_and_architecture">Art and architecture</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Russian_artists" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian artists">Russian artists</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russian_architecture" title="Russian architecture">Russian architecture</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Russian_architects" title="List of Russian architects">List of Russian architects</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:344px;max-width:344px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:123px;max-width:123px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Angelsatmamre-trinity-rublev-1410.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Angelsatmamre-trinity-rublev-1410.jpg/121px-Angelsatmamre-trinity-rublev-1410.jpg" decoding="async" width="121" height="151" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Angelsatmamre-trinity-rublev-1410.jpg/182px-Angelsatmamre-trinity-rublev-1410.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Angelsatmamre-trinity-rublev-1410.jpg/242px-Angelsatmamre-trinity-rublev-1410.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1300" data-file-height="1619"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Andrei_Rublev" title="Andrei Rublev">Andrei Rublev</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/Trinity_(Andrei_Rublev)" title="Trinity (Andrei Rublev)">Trinity</a></i> (1425)
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:217px;max-width:217px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Karl_Brullov_-_The_Last_Day_of_Pompeii_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Karl_Brullov_-_The_Last_Day_of_Pompeii_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/215px-Karl_Brullov_-_The_Last_Day_of_Pompeii_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" decoding="async" width="215" height="151" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Karl_Brullov_-_The_Last_Day_of_Pompeii_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/323px-Karl_Brullov_-_The_Last_Day_of_Pompeii_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Karl_Brullov_-_The_Last_Day_of_Pompeii_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/430px-Karl_Brullov_-_The_Last_Day_of_Pompeii_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg 2x" data-file-width="30000" data-file-height="21059"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Karl_Bryullov" title="Karl Bryullov">Karl Bryullov</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Last_Day_of_Pompeii" title="The Last Day of Pompeii">The Last Day of Pompeii</a></i> (1833)
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Early Russian painting is represented in <a href="/wiki/Russian_icons" title="Russian icons">icons</a> and vibrant <a href="/wiki/Fresco" title="Fresco">frescos</a>. As Moscow rose to power, <a href="/wiki/Theophanes_the_Greek" title="Theophanes the Greek">Theophanes the Greek</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dionisius" title="Dionisius">Dionisius</a> and <a href="/wiki/Andrei_Rublev" title="Andrei Rublev">Andrei Rublev</a> became vital names in Russian art. The <a href="/wiki/Russian_Academy_of_Arts" title="Russian Academy of Arts">Russian Academy of Arts</a> was created in 1757. In the 18th century, academicians <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Argunov" title="Ivan Argunov">Ivan Argunov</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dmitry_Levitzky" title="Dmitry Levitzky">Dmitry Levitzky</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Borovikovsky" title="Vladimir Borovikovsky">Vladimir Borovikovsky</a> became influential. The early 19th century saw many prominent paintings by <a href="/wiki/Karl_Briullov" class="mw-redirect" title="Karl Briullov">Karl Briullov</a> and <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Andreyevich_Ivanov" title="Alexander Andreyevich Ivanov">Alexander Ivanov</a>. In the mid-19th century, the group of mostly <a href="/wiki/Realism_(arts)" title="Realism (arts)">realists</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Peredvizhniki" title="Peredvizhniki">Peredvizhniki</a></i> broke with the Academy. Leading Russian realists include <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Shishkin" title="Ivan Shishkin">Ivan Shishkin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arkhip_Kuindzhi" title="Arkhip Kuindzhi">Arkhip Kuindzhi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Kramskoi" title="Ivan Kramskoi">Ivan Kramskoi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vasily_Polenov" title="Vasily Polenov">Vasily Polenov</a>, <a href="/wiki/Isaac_Levitan" title="Isaac Levitan">Isaac Levitan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vasily_Surikov" title="Vasily Surikov">Vasily Surikov</a>, <a href="/wiki/Viktor_Vasnetsov" title="Viktor Vasnetsov">Viktor Vasnetsov</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ilya_Repin" title="Ilya Repin">Ilya Repin</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Boris_Kustodiev" title="Boris Kustodiev">Boris Kustodiev</a>. The turn of the 20th century saw the rise of <a href="/wiki/Symbolism_(arts)" title="Symbolism (arts)">symbolism</a>; represented by <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Vrubel" title="Mikhail Vrubel">Mikhail Vrubel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kuzma_Petrov-Vodkin" title="Kuzma Petrov-Vodkin">Kuzma Petrov-Vodkin</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Nicholas_Roerich" title="Nicholas Roerich">Nicholas Roerich</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Russian_avant-garde" title="Russian avant-garde">Russian avant-garde</a> flourished from approximately 1890 to 1930; notable artists from this era were <a href="/wiki/El_Lissitzky" title="El Lissitzky">El Lissitzky</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kazimir_Malevich" title="Kazimir Malevich">Kazimir Malevich</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wassily_Kandinsky" title="Wassily Kandinsky">Wassily Kandinsky</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Marc_Chagall" title="Marc Chagall">Marc Chagall</a>. Some influential Soviet sculptures were <a href="/wiki/Vera_Mukhina" title="Vera Mukhina">Vera Mukhina</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yevgeny_Vuchetich" title="Yevgeny Vuchetich">Yevgeny Vuchetich</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ernst_Neizvestny" title="Ernst Neizvestny">Ernst Neizvestny</a>. </p>
      <p>Beginning with the woodcraft buildings of ancient <a href="/wiki/Slavs" title="Slavs">Slavs</a>; since the <a href="/wiki/Christianization_of_Kievan_Rus%27" title="Christianization of Kievan Rus'">Christianization of Kievan Rus'</a>, for several centuries Russian architecture was influenced predominantly by <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_architecture" title="Byzantine architecture">Byzantine architecture</a>. <a href="/wiki/Aristotle_Fioravanti" class="mw-redirect" title="Aristotle Fioravanti">Aristotle Fioravanti</a> and other Italian architects brought <a href="/wiki/Renaissance" title="Renaissance">Renaissance</a> trends into Russia. The 16th century saw the development of the unique <a href="/wiki/Tent-like_church" class="mw-redirect" title="Tent-like church">tent-like churches</a>; and the <a href="/wiki/Onion_dome" title="Onion dome">onion dome</a> design. In the 17th century, the "fiery style" of ornamentation flourished in Moscow and <a href="/wiki/Yaroslavl" title="Yaroslavl">Yaroslavl</a>, gradually paving the way for the <a href="/wiki/Naryshkin_baroque" class="mw-redirect" title="Naryshkin baroque">Naryshkin baroque</a> of the 1690s. After the <a href="/wiki/Reforms_of_Peter_I_of_Russia" class="mw-redirect" title="Reforms of Peter I of Russia">reforms of Peter the Great</a>; the country's architecture became influenced by Western Europe. The 18th-century taste for <a href="/wiki/Rococo" title="Rococo">Rococo</a> architecture led to the splendid works of <a href="/wiki/Bartolomeo_Rastrelli" class="mw-redirect" title="Bartolomeo Rastrelli">Bartolomeo Rastrelli</a> and his followers. During the reign of <a href="/wiki/Catherine_the_Great" title="Catherine the Great">Catherine the Great</a> and her grandson <a href="/wiki/Alexander_I_of_Russia" title="Alexander I of Russia">Alexander I</a>, the city of <a href="/wiki/Saint_Petersburg" title="Saint Petersburg">Saint Petersburg</a> was transformed into an outdoor museum of <a href="/wiki/Neoclassical_architecture" title="Neoclassical architecture">Neoclassical architecture</a>. The second half of the 19th century was dominated by the Byzantine and <a href="/wiki/Russian_Revival" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian Revival">Russian Revival</a> style. Prevalent styles of the 20th century were the <a href="/wiki/Art_Nouveau" title="Art Nouveau">Art Nouveau</a> (<a href="/wiki/Fyodor_Shekhtel" class="mw-redirect" title="Fyodor Shekhtel">Fyodor Shekhtel</a>), <a href="/wiki/Constructivism_(art)" title="Constructivism (art)">Constructivism</a> (<a href="/wiki/Moisei_Ginzburg" title="Moisei Ginzburg">Moisei Ginzburg</a> and <a href="/wiki/Victor_Vesnin" class="mw-redirect" title="Victor Vesnin">Victor Vesnin</a>), and <a href="/wiki/Stalinist_architecture" title="Stalinist architecture">Socialist Classicism</a> (<a href="/wiki/Boris_Iofan" title="Boris Iofan">Boris Iofan</a>). </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Music">Music</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Russia" title="Music of Russia">Music of Russia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Portr%C3%A4t_des_Komponisten_Pjotr_I._Tschaikowski_(1840-1893).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Portr%C3%A4t_des_Komponisten_Pjotr_I._Tschaikowski_%281840-1893%29.jpg/170px-Portr%C3%A4t_des_Komponisten_Pjotr_I._Tschaikowski_%281840-1893%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="218" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Portr%C3%A4t_des_Komponisten_Pjotr_I._Tschaikowski_%281840-1893%29.jpg/255px-Portr%C3%A4t_des_Komponisten_Pjotr_I._Tschaikowski_%281840-1893%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Portr%C3%A4t_des_Komponisten_Pjotr_I._Tschaikowski_%281840-1893%29.jpg/340px-Portr%C3%A4t_des_Komponisten_Pjotr_I._Tschaikowski_%281840-1893%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="883" data-file-height="1134"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Portr%C3%A4t_des_Komponisten_Pjotr_I._Tschaikowski_(1840-1893).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Pyotr_Ilyich_Tchaikovsky" title="Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky">Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky</a> (1840â1893), composer
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Music in 19th-century Russia was defined by the tension between classical composer <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Glinka" title="Mikhail Glinka">Mikhail Glinka</a> along with other members of <a href="/wiki/The_Mighty_Handful" class="mw-redirect" title="The Mighty Handful">The Mighty Handful</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Musical_Society" title="Russian Musical Society">Russian Musical Society</a> led by composers <a href="/wiki/Anton_Rubinstein" title="Anton Rubinstein">Anton</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nikolay_Rubinstein" class="mw-redirect" title="Nikolay Rubinstein">Nikolay Rubinstein</a>. The later tradition of <a href="/wiki/Pyotr_Ilyich_Tchaikovsky" title="Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky">Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky</a>, one of the greatest composers of the <a href="/wiki/Romantic_music" title="Romantic music">Romantic era</a>, was continued into the 20th century by <a href="/wiki/Sergei_Rachmaninoff" title="Sergei Rachmaninoff">Sergei Rachmaninoff</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-287" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-287">[279]</a></sup> World-renowned composers of the 20th century include <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Scriabin" title="Alexander Scriabin">Alexander Scriabin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Igor_Stravinsky" title="Igor Stravinsky">Igor Stravinsky</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sergei_Prokofiev" title="Sergei Prokofiev">Sergei Prokofiev</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dmitri_Shostakovich" title="Dmitri Shostakovich">Dmitri Shostakovich</a> and <a href="/wiki/Alfred_Schnittke" title="Alfred Schnittke">Alfred Schnittke</a>. </p>
      <p>Russian conservatories have turned out generations of famous soloists. Among the best known are violinists <a href="/wiki/Jascha_Heifetz" title="Jascha Heifetz">Jascha Heifetz</a>, <a href="/wiki/David_Oistrakh" title="David Oistrakh">David Oistrakh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Leonid_Kogan" title="Leonid Kogan">Leonid Kogan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gidon_Kremer" title="Gidon Kremer">Gidon Kremer</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Maxim_Vengerov" title="Maxim Vengerov">Maxim Vengerov</a>; cellists <a href="/wiki/Mstislav_Rostropovich" title="Mstislav Rostropovich">Mstislav Rostropovich</a>, <a href="/wiki/Natalia_Gutman" title="Natalia Gutman">Natalia Gutman</a>; pianists <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Horowitz" title="Vladimir Horowitz">Vladimir Horowitz</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sviatoslav_Richter" title="Sviatoslav Richter">Sviatoslav Richter</a>, <a href="/wiki/Emil_Gilels" title="Emil Gilels">Emil Gilels</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Sofronitsky" title="Vladimir Sofronitsky">Vladimir Sofronitsky</a> and <a href="/wiki/Evgeny_Kissin" title="Evgeny Kissin">Evgeny Kissin</a>; and vocalists <a href="/wiki/Fyodor_Shalyapin" class="mw-redirect" title="Fyodor Shalyapin">Fyodor Shalyapin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mark_Reizen" title="Mark Reizen">Mark Reizen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Elena_Obraztsova" title="Elena Obraztsova">Elena Obraztsova</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tamara_Sinyavskaya" title="Tamara Sinyavskaya">Tamara Sinyavskaya</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nina_Dorliak" title="Nina Dorliak">Nina Dorliak</a>, <a href="/wiki/Galina_Vishnevskaya" title="Galina Vishnevskaya">Galina Vishnevskaya</a>, <a href="/wiki/Anna_Netrebko" title="Anna Netrebko">Anna Netrebko</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dmitry_Hvorostovsky" class="mw-redirect" title="Dmitry Hvorostovsky">Dmitry Hvorostovsky</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-288" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-288">[280]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Modern <a href="/wiki/Russian_rock" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian rock">Russian rock</a> music takes its roots both in the Western <a href="/wiki/Rock_and_roll" title="Rock and roll">rock and roll</a> and <a href="/wiki/Heavy_metal_music" title="Heavy metal music">heavy metal</a>, and in traditions of the <a href="/wiki/Russian_bards" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian bards">Russian bards</a> of the Soviet era, such as <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Vysotsky" title="Vladimir Vysotsky">Vladimir Vysotsky</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bulat_Okudzhava" title="Bulat Okudzhava">Bulat Okudzhava</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-289" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-289">[281]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Russian_pop" title="Russian pop">Russian pop</a> music developed from what was known in the Soviet times as <i>estrada</i> into full-fledged industry. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature_and_philosophy">Literature and philosophy</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Russian_literature" title="Russian literature">Russian literature</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russian_philosophy" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian philosophy">Russian philosophy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russian_poets" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian poets">Russian poets</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russian_playwrights" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian playwrights">Russian playwrights</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russian_novelists" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian novelists">Russian novelists</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Russian_science_fiction_and_fantasy" title="Russian science fiction and fantasy">Russian science fiction and fantasy</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Ilya_Efimovich_Repin_(1844-1930)_-_Portrait_of_Leo_Tolstoy_(1887).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Ilya_Efimovich_Repin_%281844-1930%29_-_Portrait_of_Leo_Tolstoy_%281887%29.jpg/170px-Ilya_Efimovich_Repin_%281844-1930%29_-_Portrait_of_Leo_Tolstoy_%281887%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="231" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Ilya_Efimovich_Repin_%281844-1930%29_-_Portrait_of_Leo_Tolstoy_%281887%29.jpg/255px-Ilya_Efimovich_Repin_%281844-1930%29_-_Portrait_of_Leo_Tolstoy_%281887%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Ilya_Efimovich_Repin_%281844-1930%29_-_Portrait_of_Leo_Tolstoy_%281887%29.jpg/340px-Ilya_Efimovich_Repin_%281844-1930%29_-_Portrait_of_Leo_Tolstoy_%281887%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1508" data-file-height="2048"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Ilya_Efimovich_Repin_(1844-1930)_-_Portrait_of_Leo_Tolstoy_(1887).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Leo_Tolstoy" title="Leo Tolstoy">Leo Tolstoy</a> is regarded as one of the greatest authors of all time.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Traced back to the <a href="/wiki/Middle_Ages" title="Middle Ages">Middle Ages</a>, when epics and chronicles in <a href="/wiki/Old_East_Slavic" title="Old East Slavic">Old East Slavic</a> were composed, in the 18th century, by the <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Enlightenment" title="Age of Enlightenment">Age of Enlightenment</a>, the works of <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Lomonosov" title="Mikhail Lomonosov">Mikhail Lomonosov</a> and <a href="/wiki/Denis_Fonvizin" title="Denis Fonvizin">Denis Fonvizin</a> boosted <a href="/wiki/Russian_literature" title="Russian literature">Russian literature</a>. The early 19th century began with <a href="/wiki/Vasily_Zhukovsky" title="Vasily Zhukovsky">Vasily Zhukovsky</a> and <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Pushkin" title="Alexander Pushkin">Alexander Pushkin</a>; who is considered by many to be the greatest Russian poet.<sup id="cite_ref-290" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-290">[282]</a></sup> It continued with the poetry of <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Lermontov" title="Mikhail Lermontov">Mikhail Lermontov</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nikolay_Nekrasov" title="Nikolay Nekrasov">Nikolay Nekrasov</a>, dramas of <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Ostrovsky" title="Alexander Ostrovsky">Alexander Ostrovsky</a> and <a href="/wiki/Anton_Chekhov" title="Anton Chekhov">Anton Chekhov</a>, and the prose of <a href="/wiki/Nikolai_Gogol" title="Nikolai Gogol">Nikolai Gogol</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Turgenev" title="Ivan Turgenev">Ivan Turgenev</a>. <a href="/wiki/Leo_Tolstoy" title="Leo Tolstoy">Leo Tolstoy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fyodor_Dostoyevsky" class="mw-redirect" title="Fyodor Dostoyevsky">Fyodor Dostoyevsky</a> have been described by literary critics as the greatest novelists of all time.<sup id="cite_ref-291" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-291">[283]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-292" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-292">[284]</a></sup> The next several decades had leading authors such as <a href="/wiki/Konstantin_Balmont" title="Konstantin Balmont">Konstantin Balmont</a>, <a href="/wiki/Valery_Bryusov" title="Valery Bryusov">Valery Bryusov</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vyacheslav_Ivanov_(poet)" title="Vyacheslav Ivanov (poet)">Vyacheslav Ivanov</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Blok" title="Alexander Blok">Alexander Blok</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nikolay_Gumilev" class="mw-redirect" title="Nikolay Gumilev">Nikolay Gumilev</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dmitry_Merezhkovsky" title="Dmitry Merezhkovsky">Dmitry Merezhkovsky</a>, <a href="/wiki/Anna_Akhmatova" title="Anna Akhmatova">Anna Akhmatova</a> and <a href="/wiki/Boris_Pasternak" title="Boris Pasternak">Boris Pasternak</a>, and novelists <a href="/wiki/Leonid_Andreyev" title="Leonid Andreyev">Leonid Andreyev</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Bunin" title="Ivan Bunin">Ivan Bunin</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Maxim_Gorky" title="Maxim Gorky">Maxim Gorky</a>. </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Russian_philosophy" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian philosophy">Russian philosophy</a> blossomed in the 19th century; with the works of <a href="/wiki/Nikolai_Danilevsky" class="mw-redirect" title="Nikolai Danilevsky">Nikolai Danilevsky</a> and <a href="/wiki/Konstantin_Leontiev" title="Konstantin Leontiev">Konstantin Leontiev</a>. Notable philosophers of the late 19th and the early 20th centuries include <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Solovyov_(philosopher)" title="Vladimir Solovyov (philosopher)">Vladimir Solovyev</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sergei_Bulgakov" title="Sergei Bulgakov">Sergei Bulgakov</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Vernadsky" title="Vladimir Vernadsky">Vladimir Vernadsky</a>. </p>
      <p>Following the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Revolution" title="Russian Revolution">Russian Revolution</a>, many prominent writers and philosophers left the country; while a new generation of authors joined together in an effort to create a distinctive <a href="/wiki/Working-class_culture" title="Working-class culture">working-class culture</a> appropriate for the new Soviet state. Leading authors of the Soviet era include novelists <a href="/wiki/Yevgeny_Zamyatin" title="Yevgeny Zamyatin">Yevgeny Zamyatin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ilf_and_Petrov" title="Ilf and Petrov">Ilf and Petrov</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Bulgakov" title="Mikhail Bulgakov">Mikhail Bulgakov</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Sholokhov" title="Mikhail Sholokhov">Mikhail Sholokhov</a>, and poets <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Mayakovsky" title="Vladimir Mayakovsky">Vladimir Mayakovsky</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yevgeny_Yevtushenko" title="Yevgeny Yevtushenko">Yevgeny Yevtushenko</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Andrey_Voznesensky" class="mw-redirect" title="Andrey Voznesensky">Andrey Voznesensky</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Russian_cuisine" title="Russian cuisine">Russian cuisine</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Mint_bread_kvas.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Mint_bread_kvas.jpg/220px-Mint_bread_kvas.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="144" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Mint_bread_kvas.jpg/330px-Mint_bread_kvas.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Mint_bread_kvas.jpg/440px-Mint_bread_kvas.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="669"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Mint_bread_kvas.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Kvass" title="Kvass">Kvass</a>, a bread-based drink and a key ingredient in many soups.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Russian_cuisine" title="Russian cuisine">Russian cuisine</a> widely uses fish, caviar, poultry, mushrooms, berries, and honey. Crops of <a href="/wiki/Rye" title="Rye">rye</a>, wheat, <a href="/wiki/Barley" title="Barley">barley</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Millet" title="Millet">millet</a> provide the ingredients for various breads, <a href="/wiki/Pancake" title="Pancake">pancakes</a> and cereals, as well as for <a href="/wiki/Kvass" title="Kvass">kvass</a>, beer and vodka drinks. <a href="/wiki/Black_bread" class="mw-redirect" title="Black bread">Black bread</a> is very popular in Russia. Flavourful soups and stews include <a href="/wiki/Shchi" title="Shchi">shchi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Borsch" class="mw-redirect" title="Borsch">borsch</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ukha" title="Ukha">ukha</a>, <a href="/wiki/Solyanka" title="Solyanka">solyanka</a> and <a href="/wiki/Okroshka" title="Okroshka">okroshka</a>. <a href="/wiki/Smetana_(dairy_product)" title="Smetana (dairy product)">Smetana</a> (a heavy <a href="/wiki/Sour_cream" title="Sour cream">sour cream</a>) is often added to soups and salads. <a href="/wiki/Pirozhki" title="Pirozhki">Pirozhki</a>, <a href="/wiki/Blini" title="Blini">blini</a> and <a href="/wiki/Syrniki" title="Syrniki">syrniki</a> are native types of pancakes. <a href="/wiki/Chicken_Kiev" title="Chicken Kiev">Chicken Kiev</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pelmeni" title="Pelmeni">pelmeni</a> and <a href="/wiki/Shashlyk" class="mw-redirect" title="Shashlyk">shashlyk</a> are popular meat dishes, the last two being of Tatar and Caucasian origin respectively. Other meat dishes include stuffed cabbage rolls <i>(<a href="/wiki/Golubtsy" class="mw-redirect" title="Golubtsy">golubtsy</a>)</i> usually filled with meat.<sup id="cite_ref-mrig-golubtsy_293-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mrig-golubtsy-293">[285]</a></sup> Salads include <a href="/wiki/Olivier_salad" title="Olivier salad">Olivier salad</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vinegret" title="Vinegret">vinegret</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dressed_herring" title="Dressed herring">dressed herring</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Media">Media</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Media_of_Russia" class="mw-redirect" title="Media of Russia">Media of Russia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Russia" title="Cinema of Russia">Cinema of Russia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Vintage_Potemkin.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Vintage_Potemkin.jpg/170px-Vintage_Potemkin.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="240" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Vintage_Potemkin.jpg/255px-Vintage_Potemkin.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Vintage_Potemkin.jpg/340px-Vintage_Potemkin.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3541" data-file-height="5000"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Vintage_Potemkin.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Poster of <i><a href="/wiki/Battleship_Potemkin" title="Battleship Potemkin">Battleship Potemkin</a></i> (1925) by <a href="/wiki/Sergei_Eisenstein" title="Sergei Eisenstein">Sergei Eisenstein</a>, which was named the <a href="/wiki/List_of_films_considered_the_best" title="List of films considered the best">greatest film of all time</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Expo_58" title="Expo 58">Brussels World's Fair</a> in 1958
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The largest internationally operating news agencies in Russia are <a href="/wiki/TASS" title="TASS">TASS</a>, <a href="/wiki/RIA_Novosti" title="RIA Novosti">RIA Novosti</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Interfax" title="Interfax">Interfax</a>. <a href="/wiki/Television_in_Russia" title="Television in Russia">Television</a> is the most popular media in Russia, with 74% of the population watching national television channels routinely, and 59% routinely watching regional channels. There are three main nationwide radio stations in Russia: <a href="/wiki/Radio_Russia" class="mw-redirect" title="Radio Russia">Radio Russia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Radio_Mayak" title="Radio Mayak">Radio Mayak</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Radio_Yunost" title="Radio Yunost">Radio Yunost</a>. Russia has the <a href="/wiki/Video_games_in_Russia" title="Video games in Russia">largest video gaming market</a> in Europe, with over 65 million players nationwide.<sup id="cite_ref-294" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-294">[286]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Russian and later <a href="/wiki/Soviet_cinema" class="mw-redirect" title="Soviet cinema">Soviet cinema</a> was a hotbed of invention, resulting in world-renowned films such as <i><a href="/wiki/The_Battleship_Potemkin" class="mw-redirect" title="The Battleship Potemkin">The Battleship Potemkin</a></i>. Soviet-era filmmakers, most notably <a href="/wiki/Sergei_Eisenstein" title="Sergei Eisenstein">Sergei Eisenstein</a> and <a href="/wiki/Andrei_Tarkovsky" title="Andrei Tarkovsky">Andrei Tarkovsky</a>, would become some of the world's most innovative and influential directors. <a href="/wiki/Lev_Kuleshov" title="Lev Kuleshov">Lev Kuleshov</a> developed the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_montage_theory" title="Soviet montage theory">Soviet montage theory</a>; and <a href="/wiki/Dziga_Vertov" title="Dziga Vertov">Dziga Vertov</a>'s "film-eye" theory had a huge impact on the development of documentary film making and cinema realism. Many Soviet socialist realism films were artistically successful, including <i><a href="/wiki/Chapaev_(film)" title="Chapaev (film)">Chapaev</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Cranes_Are_Flying" title="The Cranes Are Flying">The Cranes Are Flying</a></i>, and <i><a href="/wiki/Ballad_of_a_Soldier" title="Ballad of a Soldier">Ballad of a Soldier</a></i>. </p>
      <p>The 1960s and 1970s saw a greater variety of artistic styles in Soviet cinema. <a href="/wiki/Eldar_Ryazanov" title="Eldar Ryazanov">Eldar Ryazanov</a>'s and <a href="/wiki/Leonid_Gaidai" title="Leonid Gaidai">Leonid Gaidai</a>'s comedies of that time were immensely popular, with many of the catch phrases still in use today. In 1961â68 <a href="/wiki/Sergey_Bondarchuk" class="mw-redirect" title="Sergey Bondarchuk">Sergey Bondarchuk</a> directed an <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award" class="mw-redirect" title="Academy Award">Oscar</a>-winning <a href="/wiki/War_and_Peace_(film_series)" title="War and Peace (film series)">film adaptation</a> of Leo Tolstoy's epic <i><a href="/wiki/War_and_Peace" title="War and Peace">War and Peace</a></i>, which was <a href="/wiki/The_most_expensive_film" class="mw-redirect" title="The most expensive film">the most expensive film</a> made in the Soviet Union.<sup id="cite_ref-295" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-295">[287]</a></sup> In 1969, <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Motyl" title="Vladimir Motyl">Vladimir Motyl</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/White_Sun_of_the_Desert" title="White Sun of the Desert">White Sun of the Desert</a></i> was released, a very popular film in a genre of <a href="/wiki/Ostern" title="Ostern">ostern</a>; the film is traditionally watched by <a href="/wiki/Cosmonauts" class="mw-redirect" title="Cosmonauts">cosmonauts</a> before any trip into space.<sup id="cite_ref-296" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-296">[288]</a></sup> In 2002, <i><a href="/wiki/Russian_Ark" title="Russian Ark">Russian Ark</a></i> was the first feature film ever to be shot in a single take. Today, Russian cinema industry continues to expand and receive international recognition. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_Russia" title="Sport in Russia">Sport in Russia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Portugal-Marocco_2.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Portugal-Marocco_2.jpg/220px-Portugal-Marocco_2.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Portugal-Marocco_2.jpg/330px-Portugal-Marocco_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Portugal-Marocco_2.jpg/440px-Portugal-Marocco_2.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4032" data-file-height="3024"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Portugal-Marocco_2.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Luzhniki_Stadium" title="Luzhniki Stadium">Luzhniki Stadium</a> in <a href="/wiki/Moscow" title="Moscow">Moscow</a>, which hosted games of the <a href="/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup" title="2018 FIFA World Cup">2018 FIFA World Cup</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">Football</a> is one of the most popular sports in Russia. The Soviet national team became the first European Champions by winning <a href="/wiki/Euro_1960" class="mw-redirect" title="Euro 1960">Euro 1960</a>; and reached the finals of <a href="/wiki/Euro_1988" class="mw-redirect" title="Euro 1988">Euro 1988</a>. In 1956 and 1988, the Soviet Union won gold at the <a href="/wiki/Football_at_the_Summer_Olympics#Men's_results" title="Football at the Summer Olympics">Olympic football tournament</a>. Russian clubs <a href="/wiki/PFC_CSKA_Moscow" title="PFC CSKA Moscow">CSKA Moscow</a> and <a href="/wiki/Zenit_Saint_Petersburg" class="mw-redirect" title="Zenit Saint Petersburg">Zenit Saint Petersburg</a> won the <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Cup" class="mw-redirect" title="UEFA Cup">UEFA Cup</a> in 2005 and 2008. The <a href="/wiki/Russian_national_football_team" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian national football team">Russian national football team</a> reached the semi-finals of <a href="/wiki/Euro_2008" class="mw-redirect" title="Euro 2008">Euro 2008</a>. Russia was the host nation for the <a href="/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup" title="2018 FIFA World Cup">2018 FIFA World Cup</a>, the first football <a href="/wiki/World_cup" title="World cup">world cup</a> ever held in Eastern Europe. </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Ice_hockey" title="Ice hockey">Ice hockey</a> is very popular in Russia; and it won the <a href="/wiki/1993_IIHF_World_Championship" class="mw-redirect" title="1993 IIHF World Championship">1993</a>, <a href="/wiki/2008_IIHF_World_Championship" title="2008 IIHF World Championship">2008</a>, <a href="/wiki/2009_IIHF_World_Championship" title="2009 IIHF World Championship">2009</a>, <a href="/wiki/2012_IIHF_World_Championship" title="2012 IIHF World Championship">2012</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/2014_IIHF_World_Championship" title="2014 IIHF World Championship">2014 IIHF World Championships</a>. <a href="/wiki/Bandy" title="Bandy">Bandy</a> is another traditionally popular ice sport in the country. The Soviet Union won all the <a href="/wiki/Bandy_World_Championship" title="Bandy World Championship">Bandy World Championships</a> for men between 1957 and 1979,<sup id="cite_ref-297" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-297">[289]</a></sup> and some thereafter too. The <a href="/wiki/Russian_national_basketball_team" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian national basketball team">Russian national basketball team</a> won the <a href="/wiki/EuroBasket_2007" title="EuroBasket 2007">EuroBasket 2007</a>; and the Russian basketball club <a href="/wiki/PBC_CSKA_Moscow" title="PBC CSKA Moscow">PBC CSKA Moscow</a> won the <a href="/wiki/Euroleague" class="mw-redirect" title="Euroleague">Euroleague</a> in <a href="/wiki/2005%E2%80%9306_Euroleague" title="2005â06 Euroleague">2006</a> and <a href="/wiki/2007%E2%80%9308_Euroleague" title="2007â08 Euroleague">2008</a>. <a href="/wiki/Formula_One" title="Formula One">Formula One</a> is also becoming increasingly popular in Russia. </p>
      <p>Historically, <a href="/wiki/Russia_at_the_Olympics" title="Russia at the Olympics">Russian athletes</a> have been one of the most successful contenders in the <a href="/wiki/Olympic_Games" title="Olympic Games">Olympic Games</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-Parks2016_298-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Parks2016-298">[290]</a></sup> ranking third in an <a href="/wiki/All-time_Olympic_Games_medal_table" title="All-time Olympic Games medal table">all-time Olympic Games medal count</a>. <a href="/wiki/Larisa_Latynina" title="Larisa Latynina">Larisa Latynina</a> holds the record for the most gold Olympic medals won by a woman. Olympic gold medalist <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Popov_(swimmer)" title="Alexander Popov (swimmer)">Alexander Popov</a> is widely considered the greatest sprint swimmer in history.<sup id="cite_ref-GrassoMallon2015_299-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GrassoMallon2015-299">[291]</a></sup> Russia is the leading nation in <a href="/wiki/Rhythmic_gymnastics" title="Rhythmic gymnastics">rhythmic gymnastics</a>; and Russian <a href="/wiki/Synchronized_swimming" title="Synchronized swimming">synchronized swimming</a> is the best in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-300" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-300">[292]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Figure_skating" title="Figure skating">Figure skating</a> is another popular sport in Russia, especially <a href="/wiki/Pair_skating" title="Pair skating">pair skating</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ice_dancing" class="mw-redirect" title="Ice dancing">ice dancing</a>. Russia has produced a number of famous <a href="/wiki/Tennis" title="Tennis">tennis</a> players, including <a href="/wiki/Maria_Sharapova" title="Maria Sharapova">Maria Sharapova</a>. <a href="/wiki/Chess" title="Chess">Chess</a> is also a widely popular pastime. The <a href="/wiki/1980_Summer_Olympic_Games" class="mw-redirect" title="1980 Summer Olympic Games">1980 Summer Olympic Games</a> were held in Moscow, and the <a href="/wiki/2014_Winter_Olympics" title="2014 Winter Olympics">2014 Winter Olympics</a> and the <a href="/wiki/2014_Winter_Paralympics" title="2014 Winter Paralympics">2014 Winter Paralympics</a> were hosted in Sochi. </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2> 
      <ul>
       <li><a href="/wiki/Outline_of_Russia" title="Outline of Russia">Outline of Russia</a></li>
      </ul>

       </ul>

      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2> 
      <div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: lower-alpha;"> 
       <div class="mw-references-wrap">
        <ol class="references"> 
         <li id="cite_note-3"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-3">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Annexation_of_Crimea_by_the_Russian_Federation" title="Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation">Russian-annexed</a> <a href="/wiki/Crimea" title="Crimea">Crimea</a>, <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_General_Assembly_Resolution_68/262" title="United Nations General Assembly Resolution 68/262">internationally recognised</a> as part of <a href="/wiki/Ukraine" title="Ukraine">Ukraine</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">[1]</a></sup> is shown in light green.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">[2]</a></sup></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-Areanote-9"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Areanote_9-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">If the disputed <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Crimea" title="Republic of Crimea">Republic of Crimea</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Federal_cities_of_Russia" title="Federal cities of Russia">federal ciy</a> of <a href="/wiki/Sevastopol" title="Sevastopol">Sevastopol</a> is excluded, the total area of Russia decreases to 17,098,246&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (6,601,670&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi)<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">[7]</a></sup></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-15"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-15">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Russian: <span lang="ru" title="Russian-language text">Ð Ð¾ÑÑÐ¸Ð¹ÑÐºÐ°Ñ Ð¤ÐµÐ´ÐµÑÐ°ÑÐ¸Ñ</span>, <small><a href="/wiki/Romanization_of_Russian" title="Romanization of Russian">tr.</a></small> <i lang="ru-Latn" title="Russian-language text">Rossiyskaya Federatsiya</i>, <small>IPA:&nbsp;</small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Russian" title="Help:IPA/Russian">[rÉËsÊ²ijskÉjÉ fÊ²ÉªdÊ²ÉªËratsÉ¨jÉ]</a></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-16"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-16">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Including the disputed <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Crimea" title="Republic of Crimea">Republic of Crimea</a>, and the federal city of <a href="/wiki/Sevastopol" title="Sevastopol">Sevastopol</a>.</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-109"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-109">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Including the disputed <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Crimea" title="Republic of Crimea">Republic of Crimea</a>, and the federal city of <a href="/wiki/Sevastopol" title="Sevastopol">Sevastopol</a>.</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-145"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-145">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Russia has an additional 850&nbsp;km (530&nbsp;mi) of coastline along the Caspian Sea, which is <a href="/wiki/Landlocked_country" title="Landlocked country">landlocked</a>.</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-146"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-146">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">These points are: from the <a href="/wiki/Vistula_Spit" title="Vistula Spit">Vistula Spit</a> and the southeasternmost point of the <a href="/wiki/Kuril_Islands" title="Kuril Islands">Kuril Islands</a>. The points which are farthest separated in <a href="/wiki/Longitude" title="Longitude">longitude</a> are 6,600&nbsp;km (4,101&nbsp;mi) apart along a geodesic line. These points are: In the west, the same spit, and in the east, the <a href="/wiki/Big_Diomede_Island" class="mw-redirect" title="Big Diomede Island">Big Diomede Island</a>.</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-crimealanguages-256"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-crimealanguages_256-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-crimealanguages_256-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Annexation_of_Crimea_by_the_Russian_Federation" title="Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation">Annexed by Russia in 2014</a> Voted to join Russian Federation in 2014; recognised as a part of <a href="/wiki/Ukraine" title="Ukraine">Ukraine</a> by most of the international community.</span> </li> 
        </ol>
       </div>
      </div>

        <li id="cite_note-2"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-2">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFTaylor2014" class="citation news cs1">Taylor, Adam (22 March 2014). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/worldviews/wp/2014/03/22/crimea-has-joined-the-ranks-of-the-worlds-gray-areas-here-are-the-others-on-that-list/">"Crimea has joined the ranks of the world's 'gray areas.' Here are the others on that list"</a>. <i>The Washington Post</i><span class="reference-accessdate">.         <li id="cite_note-4"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-4">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.constitution.ru/en/10003000-04.htm">"The Constitution of the Russian Federation â Chapter 3.         <li id="cite_note-Studies2019-119"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Studies2019_119-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFInternational_Institute_for_Strategic_Studies2019" class="citation book cs1"><a href="/wiki/International_Institute_for_Strategic_Studies" title="International Institute for Strategic Studies">International Institute for Strategic Studies</a> (15 February 2019). <i>The Military Balance 2019</i>. Routledge. p.&nbsp;195. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1857439885" title="Special:BookSources/978-1857439885"><bdi>978-1857439885</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Military+Balance+2019&amp;rft.pages=195&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft.date=2019-02-15&amp;rft.isbn=978-1857439885&amp;rft.au=International+Institute+for+Strategic+Studies&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARussia" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
        <li id="cite_note-120"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-120">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://wikileaks.org/gifiles/docs/27/2704254_re-russian-reserve-forces-.html">"The Global Intelligence Files"</a>. <i>wikileaks.org</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">1 April</span> 2015</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=wikileaks.org&amp;rft.atitle=The+Global+Intelligence+Files&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwikileaks.org%2Fgifiles%2Fdocs%2F27%2F2704254_re-russian-reserve-forces-.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARussia" class="Z3988"></span> IISS listed total reserves as 20,000,000 for many years, assuming a Soviet-style callup. The potential reserve personnel of Russia may be as high as 20 million, depending on how the figures are counted.</span> </li> 
        <li id="cite_note-cia-121"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-cia_121-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-cia_121-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-cia_121-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-cia_121-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">

          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFRosstat2020" class="citation web cs1"><a href="/wiki/Russian_Federal_State_Statistics_Service" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian Federal State Statistics Service">Rosstat</a> (2020). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.gks.ru/storage/mediabank/Popul2020.xls">"ÐÑÐµÐ½ÐºÐ° ÑÐ¸ÑÐ»ÐµÐ½Ð½Ð¾ÑÑÐ¸ Ð¿Ð¾ÑÑÐ¾ÑÐ½Ð½Ð¾Ð³Ð¾ Ð½Ð°ÑÐµÐ»ÐµÐ½Ð¸Ñ Ð½Ð° 1 ÑÐ½Ð²Ð°ÑÑ 2020 Ð³Ð¾Ð´Ð° Ð¸ Ð² ÑÑÐµÐ´Ð½ÐµÐ¼ Ð·Ð° 2019 Ð³Ð¾Ð´"</a>. <i>gks.ru</i>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=gks.ru&amp;rft.atitle=%D0%9E%D1%86%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%B0+%D1%87%D0%B8%D1%81%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BD%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B8+%D0%BF%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D1%8F%D0%BD%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE+%D0%BD%D0%B0%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%8F+%D0%BD%D0%B0+1+%D1%8F%D0%BD%D0%B2%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%8F+2020+%D0%B3%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%B0+%D0%B8+%D0%B2+%D1%81%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B4%D0%BD%D0%B5%D0%BC+%D0%B7%D0%B0+2019+%D0%B3%D0%BE%D0%B4&amp;rft.date=2020&amp;rft.au=Rosstat&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.gks.ru%2Fstorage%2Fmediabank%2FPopul2020.xls&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARussia" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li>

        <li id="cite_note-253"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-253">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

        <li id="cite_note-254"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-254">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://constitution.garant.ru/region/cons_chech/chapter/baf8d0298b9a3923e3794eecbe3d1996/">"ÐÐ¾Ð½ÑÑÐ¸ÑÑÑÐ¸Ñ Ð§ÐµÑÐµÐ½ÑÐºÐ¾Ð¹ Ð ÐµÑÐ¿ÑÐ±Ð»Ð¸ÐºÐ¸ (Ð¿ÑÐ¸Ð½ÑÑÐ° 23 Ð¼Ð°ÑÑÐ° 2003 Ð³.) / ÐÐ»Ð°Ð²Ð° 1.         <li id="cite_note-262"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-262">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://constitution.garant.ru/region/cons_hakas/chapter/daf75cc17d0d1b8b796480bc59f740b8/">"ÐÐ¾Ð½ÑÑÐ¸ÑÑÑÐ¸Ñ Ð ÐµÑÐ¿ÑÐ±Ð»Ð¸ÐºÐ¸ Ð¥Ð°ÐºÐ°ÑÐ¸Ñ (Ð¿ÑÐ¸Ð½ÑÑÐ° Ð½Ð° XVII ÑÐµÑÑÐ¸Ð¸ ÐÐµÑÑÐ¾Ð²Ð½Ð¾Ð³Ð¾ Ð¡Ð¾Ð²ÐµÑÐ° Ð ÐµÑÐ¿ÑÐ±Ð»Ð¸ÐºÐ¸ Ð¥Ð°ÐºÐ°ÑÐ¸Ñ (Ð¿ÐµÑÐ²Ð¾Ð³Ð¾ ÑÐ¾Ð·ÑÐ²Ð°) 25 Ð¼Ð°Ñ 1995 Ð³Ð¾Ð´Ð°) / ÐÐ»Ð°Ð²Ð° III.         <li id="cite_note-263"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-263">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

        <li id="cite_note-268"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-268">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://constitution.garant.ru/region/cons_udmurt/chapter/1/#block_9">"ÐÐ¾Ð½ÑÑÐ¸ÑÑÑÐ¸Ñ Ð£Ð´Ð¼ÑÑÑÑÐºÐ¾Ð¹ Ð ÐµÑÐ¿ÑÐ±Ð»Ð¸ÐºÐ¸ Ð¾Ñ 7 Ð´ÐµÐºÐ°Ð±ÑÑ 1994 Ð³. / ÐÐ»Ð°Ð²Ð° 1. ÐÑÐ½Ð¾Ð²Ñ ÐÐ¾Ð½ÑÑÐ¸ÑÑÑÐ¸Ð¾Ð½Ð½Ð¾Ð³Ð¾ ÑÑÑÐ¾Ñ"</a>. <i>constitution.garant.ru</i>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=constitution.garant.ru&amp;rft.atitle=%D0%9A%D0%BE%D0%BD%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B8%D1%82%D1%83%D1%86%D0%B8%D1%8F+%D0%A3%D0%B4%D0%BC%D1%83%D1%80%D1%82%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B9+%D0%A0%D0%B5%D1%81%D0%BF%D1%83%D0%B1%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%B8+%D0%BE%D1%82+7+%D0%B4%D0%B5%D0%BA%D0%B0%D0%B1%D1%80%D1%8F+1994+%D0%B3.+%2F+%D0%93%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%B0+1.+%D0%9E%D1%81%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B2%D1%8B+%D0%9A%D0%BE%D0%BD%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B8%D1%82%D1%83%D1%86%D0%B8%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE+%D1%81%D1%82%D1%80%D0%BE%D1%8F&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fconstitution.garant.ru%2Fregion%2Fcons_udmurt%2Fchapter%2F1%2F%23block_9&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARussia" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
        <li id="cite_note-269"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-269">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://constitution.garant.ru/region/cons_saha/chapter/daf75cc17d0d1b8b796480bc59f740b8/">"ÐÐ¾Ð½ÑÑÐ¸ÑÑÑÐ¸Ñ (ÐÑÐ½Ð¾Ð²Ð½Ð¾Ð¹ ÐÐ°ÐºÐ¾Ð½) Ð ÐµÑÐ¿ÑÐ±Ð»Ð¸ÐºÐ¸ Ð¡Ð°ÑÐ° (Ð¯ÐºÑÑÐ¸Ñ) / ÐÐ»Ð°Ð²Ð° 3. ÐÐ°ÑÐ¸Ð¾Ð½Ð°Ð»ÑÐ½Ð¾-Ð³Ð¾ÑÑÐ´Ð°ÑÑÑÐ²ÐµÐ½Ð½ÑÐ¹ ÑÑÐ°ÑÑÑ, Ð°Ð´Ð¼Ð¸Ð½Ð¸ÑÑÑÐ°ÑÐ¸Ð²Ð½Ð¾-ÑÐµÑÑÐ¸ÑÐ¾ÑÐ¸Ð°Ð»ÑÐ½Ð¾Ðµ ÑÑÑÑÐ¾Ð¹ÑÑÐ²Ð¾ (ÑÑ. 36 â 53)"</a>. <i>constitution.garant.ru</i>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=constitution.garant.ru&amp;rft.atitle=%D0%9A%D0%BE%D0%BD%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B8%D1%82%D1%83%D1%86%D0%B8%D1%8F+%28%D0%9E%D1%81%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B9+%D0%97%D0%B0%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BD%29+%D0%A0%D0%B5%D1%81%D0%BF%D1%83%D0%B1%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%B8+%D0%A1%D0%B0%D1%85%D0%B0+%28%D0%AF%D0%BA%D1%83%D1%82%D0%B8%D1%8F%29+%2F+%D0%93%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%B0+3.+%D0%9D%D0%B0%D1%86%D0%B8%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%BD%D0%BE-%D0%B3%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%83%D0%B4%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B2%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9+%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%82%D1%83%D1%81%2C+%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%BC%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%81%D1%82%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%B2%D0%BD%D0%BE-%D1%82%D0%B5%D1%80%D1%80%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%B8%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B5+%D1%83%D1%81%D1%82%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B9%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B2%D0%BE+%28%D1%81%D1%82.+36+%E2%80%93+53%29&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fconstitution.garant.ru%2Fregion%2Fcons_saha%2Fchapter%2Fdaf75cc17d0d1b8b796480bc59f740b8%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARussia" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
        <li id="cite_note-270"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-270">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.pewforum.org/2017/05/10/religious-belief-and-national-belonging-in-central-and-eastern-europe/">"Religious Belief and National Belonging in Central and Eastern Europe"</a>. <i>Pew Research Center's Religion &amp; Public Life Project</i>. 10 May 2017.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Pew+Research+Center%27s+Religion+%26+Public+Life+Project&amp;rft.atitle=Religious+Belief+and+National+Belonging+in+Central+and+Eastern+Europe&amp;rft.date=2017-05-10&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.pewforum.org%2F2017%2F05%2F10%2Freligious-belief-and-national-belonging-in-central-and-eastern-europe%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARussia" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
        <li id="cite_note-271"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-271">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.pewforum.org/2017/11/08/orthodox-christianity-in-the-21st-century/">"Orthodox Christianity in the 21st Century"</a>. <i>Pew Research Center's Religion &amp; Public Life Project</i>. 10 November 2017.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Pew+Research+Center%27s+Religion+%26+Public+Life+Project&amp;rft.atitle=Orthodox+Christianity+in+the+21st+Century&amp;rft.date=2017-11-10&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.pewforum.org%2F2017%2F11%2F08%2Forthodox-christianity-in-the-21st-century%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARussia" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
        <li id="cite_note-ArenaAtlas2012-272"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-ArenaAtlas2012_272-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">There is no official census of religion in Russia, and estimates are based on surveys only. In August 2012, <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://sreda.org/arena">ARENA</a> determined that about 46.8% of Russians are Christians (including Orthodox, Catholic, Protestant, and non-denominational), which is slightly less than an absolute 50%+ majority. However, later that year the <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.levada.ru/17-12-2012/v-rossii-74-pravoslavnykh-i-7-musulman">Levada Center</a> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20121231020830/http://www.levada.ru/17-12-2012/v-rossii-74-pravoslavnykh-i-7-musulman">Archived</a> 31 December 2012 at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a> determined that 76% of Russians are Christians, and in June 2013 the <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://fom.ru/obshchestvo/10953">Public Opinion Foundation</a> determined that 65% of Russians are Christians. These findings are in line with <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.pewforum.org/2011/12/19/global-christianity-exec/">Pew</a>'s 2010 survey, which determined that 73.3% of Russians are Christians, with <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://wciom.ru/index.php?id=268&amp;uid=13365">VTSIOM</a> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20200929201730/https://wciom.ru/index.php?id=268&amp;uid=13365%2F">Archived</a> 29 September 2020 at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a>'s 2010 survey (~77% Christian), and with <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.fgi-tbff.org/sites/default/files/elfinder/FGIImages/Research/fromresearchtopolicy/ipsos_mori_briefing_pack.pdf#page=40">Ipsos MORI</a> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20130117013643/http://www.fgi-tbff.org/sites/default/files/elfinder/FGIImages/Research/fromresearchtopolicy/ipsos_mori_briefing_pack.pdf">Archived</a> 17 January 2013 at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a>'s 2011 survey (69%).</span> </li> 
        <li id="cite_note-Ogonek-273"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Ogonek_273-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><i><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.kommersant.ru/doc/1997068">ÐÐµÑÑ â Ð½Ðµ Ð²ÐµÑÑ</a></i>. "Ogonek", â 34 (5243), 27 August 2012. <i>Retrieved 24 September 2012</i>.</span> </li> 
        <li id="cite_note-274"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-274">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20151202081009/http://www.religare.ru/2_42432.html">"Archived copy" <bdi lang="ru">ÐÐ¿ÑÐ±Ð»Ð¸ÐºÐ¾Ð²Ð°Ð½Ð° Ð¿Ð¾Ð´ÑÐ¾Ð±Ð½Ð°Ñ ÑÑÐ°Ð²Ð½Ð¸ÑÐµÐ»ÑÐ½Ð°Ñ ÑÑÐ°ÑÐ¸ÑÑÐ¸ÐºÐ° ÑÐµÐ»Ð¸Ð³Ð¸Ð¾Ð·Ð½Ð¾ÑÑÐ¸ Ð² Ð Ð¾ÑÑÐ¸Ð¸ Ð¸ ÐÐ¾Ð»ÑÑÐµ</bdi></a> (in Russian).         <li id="cite_note-281"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-281">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.constitution.ru/en/10003000-03.htm">"The Constitution of the Russian Federation"</a>. <i>Article 41</i><span class="reference-accessdate">.         <li id="cite_note-282"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-282">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.newsru.com/russia/06jun2007/lukin.html"><bdi lang="ru">Ð Ð¾ÑÑÐ¸Ð¹ÑÐºÐ¸Ð¹ Ð¾Ð¼Ð±ÑÐ´ÑÐ¼ÐµÐ½ Ð±ÑÐ´ÐµÑ Ð±Ð¾ÑÐ¾ÑÑÑÑ Ñ Ð´Ð¸ÑÐºÑÐ¸Ð¼Ð¸Ð½Ð°ÑÐ¸ÐµÐ¹ Ð¿Ð¾ "Ð¿ÑÐ¾Ð¿Ð¸ÑÐºÐµ" ÑÐµÑÐµÐ· ÑÑÐ´</bdi></a> [Russian ombudsman will be fighting discrimination based on passport "registration" in the courts] (in Russian). 6 June 2007<span class="reference-accessdate">.                   <ul>
                   <li><a href="/wiki/Izba" title="Izba">Izba</a></li> 
                   <li><a href="/wiki/Faberg%C3%A9_egg" title="FabergÃ© egg">FabergÃ© egg</a></li> 
                   <li><a href="/wiki/Shashka" title="Shashka">Shashka</a></li> 
                   <li><a href="/wiki/Tula_pryanik" title="Tula pryanik">Tula pryanik</a></li>
                  </ul> 
                 </div></td>
               </tr>
              </tbody>
             </table>
            </div>

                <td class="navbox-list navbox-even" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px">

                   <li><span class="flagicon"><a href="/wiki/Russian_Soviet_Federative_Socialist_Republic" title="Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic"><img alt="Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Flag_of_the_Russian_Soviet_Federative_Socialist_Republic_%281918%E2%80%931937%29.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_Russian_Soviet_Federative_Socialist_Republic_%281918%E2%80%931937%29.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="12" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Flag_of_the_Russian_Soviet_Federative_Socialist_Republic_%281918%E2%80%931937%29.svg/35px-Flag_of_the_Russian_Soviet_Federative_Socialist_Republic_%281918%E2%80%931937%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Flag_of_the_Russian_Soviet_Federative_Socialist_Republic_%281918%E2%80%931937%29.svg/46px-Flag_of_the_Russian_Soviet_Federative_Socialist_Republic_%281918%E2%80%931937%29.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="600" data-file-height="300"></a></span> <a href="/wiki/List_of_leaders_of_the_Russian_SFSR" title="List of leaders of the Russian SFSR">1917â1922</a></li> 
                   <li><span class="flagicon"><a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union"><img alt="Soviet Union" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Flag_of_the_Soviet_Union.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_Soviet_Union.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="12" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Flag_of_the_Soviet_Union.svg/35px-Flag_of_the_Soviet_Union.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Flag_of_the_Soviet_Union.svg/46px-Flag_of_the_Soviet_Union.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="600"></a></span> <a href="/wiki/List_of_leaders_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="List of leaders of the Soviet Union">1922â1991</a></li>

                  </ul>

                <td class="navbox-abovebelow" colspan="3" style="text-align:left;">
                 <div>
                  <div class="plainlist">
                   <ul>
                    <li><sup>1</sup> <a href="/wiki/Island#Oceanic_islands" title="Island">Oceanic islands</a> within the vicinity of Europe are usually grouped with the continent even though they are not situated on its continental shelf.</li>
                    <li><sup>2</sup> Some countries completely outside the conventional geographical boundaries of Europe are commonly associated with the continent due to ethnological links.</li>
                   </ul>
                  </div>

                  </ul>

                 <div id="Asia-Pacific_Economic_Cooperation_(APEC)" style="font-size:114%;margin:0 4em">
                  <a href="/wiki/Asia-Pacific_Economic_Cooperation" title="Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation">Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC)</a>
                 </div></th>
               </tr>
               <tr>
                <th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%">Nations</th>

                 <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r992953826">

                 <div id="*_First_*_Second_*_Third_*_Fourth_*_Fifth_*_Sixth_*_Seventh_*_Eighth_*_Ninth_*_Tenth_*_Eleventh_*_Twelfth_*_Thirteenth_*_Fourteenth_*_Fifteenth">

                   <li><a href="/wiki/First_East_Asia_Summit" title="First East Asia Summit">First</a></li> 
                   <li><a href="/wiki/Second_East_Asia_Summit" title="Second East Asia Summit">Second</a></li> 
                   <li><a href="/wiki/Third_East_Asia_Summit" title="Third East Asia Summit">Third</a></li> 
                   <li><a href="/wiki/Fourth_East_Asia_Summit" title="Fourth East Asia Summit">Fourth</a></li> 
                   <li><a href="/wiki/Fifth_East_Asia_Summit" title="Fifth East Asia Summit">Fifth</a></li> 
                   <li><a href="/wiki/Sixth_East_Asia_Summit" title="Sixth East Asia Summit">Sixth</a></li> 
                   <li><a href="/wiki/Seventh_East_Asia_Summit" title="Seventh East Asia Summit">Seventh</a></li> 
                   <li><a href="/wiki/Eighth_East_Asia_Summit" title="Eighth East Asia Summit">Eighth</a></li> 
                   <li><a href="/wiki/Ninth_East_Asia_Summit" title="Ninth East Asia Summit">Ninth</a></li> 
                   <li><a href="/wiki/Tenth_East_Asia_Summit" title="Tenth East Asia Summit">Tenth</a></li> 
                   <li><a href="/wiki/Eleventh_East_Asia_Summit" title="Eleventh East Asia Summit">Eleventh</a></li> 
                   <li><a href="/wiki/Twelfth_East_Asia_Summit" title="Twelfth East Asia Summit">Twelfth</a></li> 
                   <li><a href="/wiki/Thirteenth_East_Asia_Summit" title="Thirteenth East Asia Summit">Thirteenth</a></li> 
                   <li><a href="/wiki/Fourteenth_East_Asia_Summit" title="Fourteenth East Asia Summit">Fourteenth</a></li> 
                   <li><a href="/wiki/Fifteenth_East_Asia_Summit" title="Fifteenth East Asia Summit">Fifteenth</a></li>
                  </ul> 
                 </div></td>
               </tr>

                   <li><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/03/Flag_of_Italy.svg/23px-Flag_of_Italy.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="15" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/03/Flag_of_Italy.svg/35px-Flag_of_Italy.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/03/Flag_of_Italy.svg/45px-Flag_of_Italy.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1500" data-file-height="1000">&nbsp;</span><a href="/wiki/Italy" title="Italy">Italy</a></li>

                  </ul> 
                 </div></td>
               </tr>

             </table>
            </div>

                <th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%">Guests</th>
                <td class="navbox-list navbox-odd hlist" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px">
                 <div style="padding:0em 0.25em"> 
                  <ul>
                   <li><a href="/wiki/ASEAN" title="ASEAN">ASEAN</a></li>

                   <li><a href="/wiki/Turkmenistan" title="Turkmenistan">Turkmenistan</a></li>
                  </ul> 
                 </div></td>
               </tr>
               <tr>
